column10: An amazing sequel to the previously amazing game Spelunky HD! Gonna be completely honest here, I don't know whether it was the nostalgia of HD forcing me through this or the fact that it is actually a good game I really enjoyed despite it being difficult as hell. This game has you learn from almost every single one of your deaths, you die and you think "damn why did I do that, that was completely my fault and could have avoided it", of course there is that occasional almost unavoidable death of spawning into a level and immediately having a crush block in your proximity or casually strolling through a level just to have a UFO get knocked and land right in front of your face causing an explosion. Regardless of all that it was really satisfying getting further and further each time in the game. I alt+F4'd and still do every now and then after a death but I always picked up the game again to try actually beat it [spoiler] especially beat it in all three ways. [/spoiler] I put in 400 hours into this game on Xbox as it was on Gamepass and I had a subscription for that but then it got removed off of that and I wanted to continue playing it so I bought it on here.
spelunky
remember when spelunky had game mechanics?

Been playing the original Spelunky since release and despite the upgrades made in the sequel I'd still consider the first better because it's shorter, simpler and easier. 

The second games difficulty spike is insanely beginner unfriendly and due to rng mechanics makes it so even learning the game and knowing every aspect still isn't enough to have a good run the majority of the time. Half of the traps and enemies one shot you and the ones that don't end up being a one shot anyway in unavoidable and inescapable combos way too frequently to be considered fun or balanced. Some of the series best items were nerfed so hard they're almost not worth using, for example, getting flicked by any fire damage now with a jetpack, hoverpack, or powerpack or if they hit any bomb bags/boxes which can be caused by lava, lavamanders, firebugs, firefrogs, rockdogs, magma men, flaming arrows, etc. You get one shot. Some of the series worst items were also brought back like the spiderweb gun and the baseball glove which range from useless to nearly sabotaging yourself by grabbing it. 

The secret end game path is now so difficult it's not even worth bothering trying to attempt because it would take hundreds of hours for an average person to get to and would take even longer just trying to beat. 

For the game being a painfully difficult roguelike it's also never had the best variety in any aspect of the game from items to enemies and areas with the first game having basically none of it and the second only having a couple alternate levels leaving much to be desired after playing for a long time because you end up doing the same thing over and over and it's not just not fun.

Multiplayer has also has a bug since it came out (at least on pc) where you get stuck in a syncing screen on lower delay settings unless you alt+tab in and out at the start of every level or you can have higher delay syncing settings and wait a really long time before every single level which is equally as bad if not worse.

My definitive 2D platformer.

The movement is precise and the mechanics are unique and fun. Such as the basic whip attack being instant at your back (windup) but delayed before it hits in front of you.

It's difficult, but very fair and rewarding. About 99% of deaths are your fault and you'll learn from them. There are multiple endings, branching paths and random level generation. There's a ton of replay value and short of an official Nintendo Mario roguelike, this is my absolute favorite platformer of all time.

I love this game to bits but damn is it difficult. The game has no real buffs or items that carry over runs, just characters that are cosmetic only and shortcuts that are more used for experimenting with stages since you don't get all achievments from using them and you can't really properly beat the true ending. I really like this though. There is no doubt that it is YOU that is getting better, not the game that is getting easier. The beginning is rather rough, but after a bit everything just clicks and it feels great. Also the game is not very luck based since items matter a lot less than in games such as Binding of Isaac and Risk of Rain 2 (not that those games are bad in fact I like them both a lot). This can be really nice since you don't get those boring mediocre runs with just meh items. Definitely one of my favorite platformers and roguelikes! I can't really think of any cons within the game 10/10.

Meh. It's even more a masochist's game than the last one. Apparently i am just that, because i keep playing even though it's just unfair and frustrating. It's like one step forward, two steps back each and every time. Another skeleton skull was hiding invisibly behind some foreground art, a trap is only visible by like 4 pixels, an enemy jumps from two screens away right onto your head... What's the fun in that?

In a way it feels like the whole "rogue light" approach is just a bad excuse for unfair gameplay. Well, yes, you died in an unforseeable clustf**k, but hey, that's part of the game! Yea, i'm not convinced.

And why there is still this idiotic local coop one-player-camera mode is beyond me. This is useless, as this game is hard enough for one player. Having the other 3 players basically play blindly while offscreen is just a death sentence. Are the gamedevs too stupid for a proper split screen...?

Spelunky 2 has all the qualities of an awesome jazz fusion piece. It's stylish, has impeccable timing, and refuses to tire-out. It is constantly juggling mechanics that appear simple but actually contain a great amount of depth, effortlessly rearranging precursor genre mechanics in all of their respective complexity, and stacking them together into some sort of perfect pyramid, as if there could only have been one real shape in the end. One ultimate composition.

Spelunky (2) genuinely feels like the culmination of 30 years of gaming development, designed to be as fun and as crushingly difficult as possible. And thanks to the low disk-space usage, low spec-system requirements, and the inclusion of online co-op, I'll most likely purchase it on every device that lets me get my hands on the game.

For being a Stage 1, Dwellings is too dense with high-damage arrow traps, 3 HP burrowing enemies and stunlocks. The one stage that you spend the most time in should not feel like a repetitive chore.

In later stages (especially Neo-Babylon or ice caves), there are simply too many things that can instakill you from offscreen with no way to react.

I'm not even going to talk about Cosmic Ocean. 97 levels that are all potentially filled with random instakills isn't fun. This game's design decisions seem to be influenced by the idea that randomly dying is "funny", and as such it has picked up a following as a streamerbait game. The viewers get to laugh at the funny man in the camera, reacting to an offscreen object hurtling towards them at 500 miles per hour and instantly sending them from 99 HP to instant death. Great fun for the viewers, but a waste of time for anyone who actually wants to play this game.

[h1] TLDR: 9.5/10 An excellent sequel to the perfect game. Expands upon the original Spelunky and refines it's mechanics.  [/h1]

[h3] Actual Review (No Spoilers) [/h3]
What can I say? This game is just about the best possible sequel to Spelunky we could've asked for. Spelunky 2 takes the formula from the the first game (Spelunky HD that is) and refines it down to the best possible version it can be. The movement is extremely fluid, The whip feels better than ever (especially backwhipping) and the game overall just feels so satisfying to play and learn. There's a real sense of reward as you get good enough to discover each subsequent area, and almost the entire roster of enemies and items all feel unique and fun to fight/use.

[h3] Gameplay [/h3]
I can't gush about this game enough, especially if you have friends to play it with, as it offers a different and hilarious experience. My first few hours in this game were with friends and I think that's the best possible thing you can do to get yourself into the game. Discovering all the game has to offer and laugh out loud at all the moments that you could have never predicted.

If there is one single thing to complain about with this game is unlike HD, deaths and other happenings in Spelunky 2 aren't always the fault of the player. In the first game, 99.9% of all things that go wrong are the player's fault, no matter how bullshit they may seem. But in Spelunky 2, there is a lot more that happens that feels completely out of the player's control. Altars for example can straight up just spawn in a way that they will instantly be destroyed upon loading into a level. There are various other things that you can just sum up as "getting spelunky'd" but despite all that, the vast majority of things in the game still have player-dependent outcomes. Which is why it feels so rewarding to play.

I also should talk about the music. Spelunky HD had some BANGIN tracks and this game is no different. Definitely more atmospheric than HD, but the thing is there is only one long track for each area that dips in and out of each level. In HD, there were multiple different songs that could play for each of the 4 levels in an area which gave some variety, but even without that, Spelunky 2 has some great music.

[h3] Achievements & The Completionist Grind [/h3]
Lastly, going for 100% achievements is certainly a grind. But despite the insane difficulty of it, it was actually one of my favorites to date. I got all my friends into this game at the same time so there was a very organic learning curve that we all went through at the same time which gave me more of a drive than normal to complete such a hard game. Definitely worth it if you're willing to put in the time, especially for some of the harder achievements where you're pretty much at the mercy of having good spawns and the right items in the shops.

[h3] Conclusion [/h3]
Overall this game is well worth full price and then some. Especially if you're going for completion, you'll learn the ins and outs of every area, enemy, item, and pretty much every interaction in the game. You'll master advanced tactics like bomb chucking and ledge whipping, and even get good at speedrunning just for good measure. Spelunky 2 is the full package and is a blast any way you look at it. 9.5/10

Rating: ⭐⭐⭐⭐⭐

Spelunky 2 is an absolute triumph in the world of roguelike gaming, delivering an exhilarating experience that surpasses even the lofty expectations set by its predecessor. From the moment I delved into the treacherous depths of its procedurally generated caves, I was hooked, and the game's relentless charm and challenge kept me coming back for more.

The level design is a true testament to the genius of Derek Yu and his team. The intricately crafted environments are not just visually stunning, but they also create an ever-changing landscape that challenges players to think on their feet. Every run feels fresh and unpredictable, with hidden secrets and dangers lurking around every corner. It's a testament to the game's design that even after numerous playthroughs, I continue to discover new surprises and challenges.

Spelunky 2's commitment to difficulty is both punishing and rewarding. The learning curve is steep, yet the sense of accomplishment when overcoming each hurdle is unmatched. The game constantly demands skill and strategy, making each decision a crucial one. Whether it's avoiding devious traps, outsmarting enemies, or navigating the intricate puzzles, every move requires careful consideration, adding layers of depth to the gameplay.

The addition of new characters, items, and environments enriches the overall experience, providing players with ample opportunities for experimentation and strategic planning. The expanded roster of playable characters brings diversity to the game, each with their own unique abilities and playstyles. This not only enhances the replay value but also adds an extra layer of complexity to the already challenging gameplay.

Multiplayer mode is an absolute blast, fostering both cooperation and competition among friends. The chaos that ensues when navigating the caves with a group of friends adds a whole new dimension to the Spelunky 2 experience. The shared victories and inevitable mishaps make for unforgettable gaming moments that will be recounted with laughter and excitement.

In terms of visuals and audio, Spelunky 2 excels on all fronts. The charming pixel art style is a treat for the eyes, and the dynamic soundtrack enhances the tension and excitement as you explore each level. The attention to detail in both the visual and auditory aspects of the game contributes to its immersive and engaging atmosphere.

In conclusion, Spelunky 2 is a true gem in the roguelike genre. It not only lives up to the legacy of its predecessor but also surpasses it in every conceivable way. With its challenging gameplay, ingenious level design, and a plethora of content, Spelunky 2 is a must-play for fans of the genre and newcomers alike. Brace yourself for a thrilling journey filled with surprises, setbacks, and triumphs – Spelunky 2 is a five-star adventure that will keep you coming back for more!

Rating: ★★★★★

Derek Yu and the team at Mossmouth have once again outdone themselves with the masterpiece that is Spelunky 2. As a sequel to the acclaimed original, Spelunky 2 not only lives up to the lofty expectations set by its predecessor but ascends to new heights, delivering an unparalleled rogue-like experience that is as challenging as it is captivating.

One of the game's most outstanding features is its procedurally generated levels. Each descent into the depths of Spelunky 2 is a unique adventure, an uncharted territory filled with traps, treasures, and creatures that defy expectations. The genius of the procedural generation lies in its ability to surprise even seasoned players, ensuring that no two runs ever feel the same. This dynamic world-building keeps the game endlessly engaging, fostering a sense of discovery with every step.

The meticulous attention to detail is apparent in every facet of Spelunky 2. From the charming pixel art style that retains the nostalgic essence of its predecessor to the vibrant and diverse environments, the game is a visual feast. The personality injected into each character, be it the determined spelunker or the quirky denizens of the underworld, adds a layer of charm that makes every interaction memorable.

The level of difficulty in Spelunky 2 is both punishing and rewarding. Learning from mistakes becomes a fundamental aspect of the experience, and the sense of accomplishment after overcoming a particularly challenging section or boss is immensely satisfying. The game encourages creativity, forcing players to think on their feet and adapt to the ever-changing environment.

The addition of new characters, items, and secrets elevates the gameplay to new heights. The variety of playstyles and strategies that emerge from the expansive roster of items and characters allows for a wealth of replayability. Spelunky 2's depth is not just in its caverns but in the strategic choices players make, creating an immersive and dynamic gameplay experience.

The multiplayer aspect of Spelunky 2 deserves special praise. The cooperative mode adds a whole new layer of enjoyment, fostering camaraderie as players navigate the challenging caves together. It's a testament to the game's design that multiplayer doesn't feel like an afterthought but an integral part of the Spelunky experience.

The soundtrack, composed by Eirik Suhrke, is a perfect accompaniment to the perilous journey. The music seamlessly adapts to the on-screen action, creating an atmospheric soundscape that enhances the emotional resonance of each moment, from tense encounters to triumphant victories.

In conclusion, Spelunky 2 is a triumph in game design, a shining example of how to craft a sequel that not only honors its roots but surpasses them in every way. It's a challenging, visually stunning, and endlessly rewarding adventure that will keep players spelunking into its depths for years to come. Whether you're a fan of the original or a newcomer to the series, Spelunky 2 is a must-play, setting a new standard for the rogue-like genre.

I couldn't possibly recommend Spelunky 2 for a new player.  It has little to no difficulty curve, immediately fucking you straight in the face with lots of mechanics.  Do yourself a favor, just play Spelunky 1.  

If you're a returning player, I submit that this still sucks.  I just don't find it enjoyable, and unless you're looking to punish yourself with a more challenging Spelunky right from the get-go, the fun to be had here is questionable.  I don't like looking at the game's drab color palette, the movement speed on some enemies is insane, and if the thirty different mechanics in the first world don't get you, some being fairly advanced, the mini-boss has a good shot, too.  The rest of the game keeps going in that direction, and if you want to know what something does, experimentation often equals death.

I played a metric fuckton of Spelunky 1, and it's one of my favorite difficult games of all time.  If I had known this was actually git-gud masochism and not a balanced, fluid experience like the first game, well, I still would have bought it.  But, I can't really say that you should, too.

Don't play this game. Every moment is full of glory, potential and promise, until a mole comes through a wall, throwing you into a death pit where a caveman and lizard will bounce you back and forth like a volleyball. You will never beat this game, because Derek doesn't want you to beat this game. After the unfortunate death of twiggle, he changed the game's code to make it impossible to reach the final stages of the game, cementing him in Spelunky history forever. Even if you do make it, somehow, it will be shallow, and you will feel hollow on the inside. Every accomplishment will be undermined by another empty secret room, no hit 7-99 run on YouTube, and shrineless runs. Every moment you play this will be suffering, and you will thank Derek for it.

This game made me question whether I ever actually enjoyed the original.  The original was challenging, but here everything has been cranked up to 11.  The first set of levels, which in the original were a way to ease into the game, are now a nightmarish slog, ultra dense with traps and enemies, including new enemies that are far more difficult than their predecessors.  They take multiple hits to kill (which cannot be done quickly as they are invincible during stun) and have fast, erratic movements.  Then once you graduate to the later levels, your health effectively becomes meaningless because 90% of your deaths will be 1-hit instakills, or effective 1-hit kills where you are stunlocked, thrown around the screen, and juggled to death.  The game does not even appear to be aiming for the "tough but fair" label that Souls games often get.  I experienced many deaths due to bizarre enemy interactions halfway across the map, or objects flying at me suddenly from offscreen.

What all of this added difficultly results in is a game that is at odds with itself.  It must be played with extreme caution if the player wants to have any chance of success, but this slows the pace of the game down to a crawl and draws out the length of each run.  This being a roguelike where all progress is lost upon death, this makes every death as painful and disheartening as possible.  The balance between fun and frustration has been completely lost here.

In my opinion, as an avid indie-game enjoyer/fan/player, Spelunky 2 is one of the most amazing, complex, fun, difficult, and overall a unique game! Spelunky 2 is an indie, rogue-like experience created and published by Derek  Yu and his team of amazing and talented developers. It has very fun and silly mechanics, that will never bore you, and a lot of cool and creative designs. The story is picked up after the events of Spelunky (the original instalment in the series), and straight from the get-go is a banger! The story is very unique and the cast of characters are very cool and interesting. The plot is about Ana (the main protagonist) going to the moon to search for her parents, after they went to investigate something mysterious on the moon. The world and enemy designs are very fun and creative, as most of the things are based on real-world and historical beings from folklore and tales. As a big fan of creepy monster designs, I love this idea! The game is very tough and unforgiving, and makes you want to pull your hair out, but at the same time, every death feels like your fault, so after time, you will get better. This is why I love the rogue-like genre, as they always are tough and hard to play, but once you complete them, it feels like you accomplished something, which makes you proud! This game is a masterpiece, and every single spec is pure passion. Thank you to Derek Yu and his team of wonderful devs for making this gem of a game!!

Truly a phenomenal game in my eyes and the best of the 3 current spelunky games (expectedly as it is the latest instalment). 

The greatest aspect of the spelunky experience is the quality replay-ability the game has to offer with its randomly generated rooms throughout different world types, the complex game mechanics that are simple to learn but take extensive time and dedication to master. 

Spelunky 2 is a rogue-like game, (this works well with the randomised rooms), therefore as you play you cant rely on any form of power ups for the player character across games, but you need to learn how the world around you works and how to thrive within it, this would lead the skill ceiling to be even higher.

The game has well rounded graphics and a colour pallet that is not too vibrant or abstract. Each world also has a unique theme that really makes each new location feel different, this consists of the music that seamlessly transitions through levels (10/10 but can be disabled), the huge variety of enemies that all have their own attack patterns and the style of the terrain surrounding you. These aspects lead each level to feel alive and not just a chore to get through.

This game is packed full of npcs to interact with, quest lines to do and secrets waiting to be found. And all of this is documented in a well thought out journal that can provide insight into how far you have progressed through the many hours of content waiting to be explored.

There is also a co-op mode for up to four people and this can be accessed locally or through an online feature, with this you can access the standard adventure game mode and the arena mode to battle your friends to become the ultimate spelunker.

A blend of precision platforming and roguelike elements that successfully combines the least fun problems from both genres.
The game has a lot to love in the artwork and setting, as well as fun and diverse enemies. The story is barebones but not really what people play the game for.
It's an odd game because it encourages players to "get good" at precision platforming by punishing the player hard for simple mistakes. Any slip up means you will probably lose your run immediately. It then tries to walk this back by giving the player a health bar with four hits, in order to be more forgiving. Unfortunately it then walks this back again by stun locking the player every time they are hit, so if you slip up once, youll probably be damaged multiple times from one enemy, making the entire health bar completely meaningless as a mechanic. Besides enemies, there are dozens of statuinary traps which instant-kill the player. They're actually less frustrating and pretty balanced for what they do.
The roguelike elements make the game very frustrating in comparison to others in the genre. The level generation doesnt seem to be very careful about making the floors actually playable. Getting stuck in a poorly generated room without the consumable tools to escape means you have to just restart your run. Some floors generate so you cannot progress without taking fall damage, because there's literally nothing to jump on. Sometimes the only jump down is into a spike pit, so you don't get to continue playing now. Many problems like these can be mitigated by using your consumables, but the random nature of a roguelike means you might go the whole run and never get more than you start with at the beginning.
Every run shouldn't be an easy win, but I should at least be losing because of my own mistakes. Using my consumables sparingly and still not having enough to progress doesn't feel like a "get good" issue, just a design problem.
Beside consumables, there are other items you can purchase at shops. Some shops randomly generate, others are always on the same floor every run. It can be frustrating, but at least thr game concedes some consistency.

I want to like this game more, since it's a lot of fun with friends in co op. The co-op mode has its own drawbacks though, in that you have to start from the first floor every single run, and it can get a bit chaotic with more people. Similar to Lethal Company, having things go terribly wrong can be fun with friends, even if the game restricts players from accessing late game together without sloughing through an entire run.

Single player is pretty awful. Due to the nature of small mistakes almost always killing you, the lack of reliable resources, and the difficulty of navigating the random floor designs, playing alone usually falls somewhere between bashing your head against a wall repeatedly and making small amounts of progress only to die to a randomly generated problem which you couldn't foresee or plan for.

The game is so comically RNG dependent that any real improvement in your platforming doesn't result in better performance on average. At the highest level of play (speedrunners), this can be overcome, but for the majority of players, the game is just not rewarding to even try.

This game is really tough to rate for me.
While I have beaten the game several times in various ways, I felt I merely held on because of my appreciation for Spelunky HD, wanting to dive deeper into the game attempting to get the same fun out of it as I had in learning Spelunky HD. Overall, I felt this learning experience wasn't fun, rewarding and hilarious as with the first game, but rather tedious, with certain parts becoming more and more repetitive after a while, causing me to f-up after a while because I grew so bored of for example fighting the same mini-Bosses over and over again and becoming negligent because of that.
While the first game was hard in the beginning, it could become trivial after beating it a few times, for several reasons (good items being more powerful and abundant, enemies in the first area being easier, more accessible exploits of certain mechanics). Spelunky 2 mitigates a lot of these, but doesn't succeed in creating more long term fun than Spelunky HD as a result. The first levels of the game have become considerably harder, while giving you less opportunity to get good items for the mid/late game, but also a lot of good items are nerfed, the game over all is way harder. Having the first levels of this game be very similiar in art style to the beginning of Spelunky HD, makes it even more tedious to traverse these levels carefully. The idea of having the music play continiously with elements of it changing when you reach certain points of the game is really cool! But it's a shame that it's always the same, and while I like the Idea I'd rather have it be several randomly choosen musical tracks like in the first game, or expand on the way they did it with more tracks (which I realize would be lots of work).
While the game has even more traversing paths than the first game which I love, I barely ever explored them, because I found survival to be too difficult to make me want to deviate from what I felt is the easiest path.
Derek Yu suggests viewing the game as a sandbox experience, but I find the fun of that wearing out relatively fast. Of course you want to explore and beat the game at some point. Also, when you sandbox the game you die so easily that you will not live very long..
I think it's amazing that this game has even more of the kind of challenges than Spelunky HD, which are very very hard for the average gamer, and I'm totally fine with never beating the cosmic ocean, I'm not even trying that s--t lol! But a lot of the "easier" things and endings in the game are to difficult to do to make f-ing around in the game fun for me. I feel the balance of the game is of, and makes it feel like it is tailored to  hardcore gamers too much. It feels like the developers looked at how the very best players trivialized the difficulty of the first game, and sculpted the second game too much after that, with those top players being a very small part of the player base. 
The beauty of the first game IMO was that it was difficult (but fun) to learn, while offering very difficult challenges to the hardcore crowd, which are not necessarily linked to beating the game. while this game feels tedious.
Imo, it is in a lot of ways "an amazing game which is not fun".
The frustrating thing for me is, that I feel it could have been the greatest game of all time.

The absolute best rogue-like platformer I have ever played. Spelunky HD was close to being perfect, but its sequel tops that on every level. The game is hard, but rewarding. Has a ton of secrets to uncover, a ton of tactics to learn. It seems to be completely random at first, but actually when you learn it, many things can be guaranteed within every run. Similarily to "just one more turn" aspect of turn-based games it has a "one more try" syndrome which keeps you in for long hours. Deaths may be frustrating at times, but in most cases you know you made a mistake and you learn from it. Also arenas are tons of fun in shared screen PVP.

In my opinion the best video game of all time. Never before has a game made me angry, and then laugh my ass off, and then run it back all in the span of about a minute. Spelunky 2 is responsible for so many of my headaches, not because it's aggravating or very difficult (although it is both of those sometimes) but because of dehydration as a result of the intense sweating.

If you enjoy challenging games, play it.
If you enjoy games that will fast forward you through the stages of grief, make you scream out of anger, joy, fear, and confusion, and make you and your friends freak the hell out and play it every other day for like 4 months (which happened to me) then you are doing yourself a disservice by not buying it right now and playing it immediately.

TL;DR Spelunky 2 is literally the best game.

The very first area in the game throws 2 of the toughest enemies at you immediately, and either floor you choose past this dreaded place contains its own gauntlet of badly designed horrors of traps, secrets and enemies. A boss blocks most players from enjoying the game past the first few areas, and one of the following zones contains the spammed hardest trap in the entire game as well as all 4 of the most irritating and strong enemies in the entire game all in the same area.
The final zone for standard runs also contains the perfect weakness to those who were lucky enough to find a beneficial back item, and the final boss proves almost impossible to defeat without the assistance of sticky bombs.
The final secret area contains a kind of block which will instantly kill you, as well as one final hurdle of a boss that always finds a way to kill you in the most unsuspecting way possible. 
God forbid you complete the games dubious celestial challenges along the way and enter the final challenge, a dreaded gauntlet of repetitive levels that stretches out a run from 30 minutes, to 2 hours.

Game's been out a couple of years already, so this review is... late. But, I've gotten into it much more recently, because I really wanted to [spoiler] get to that coveted Cosmic Ocean [/spoiler]. And I've found myself falling in love with this game.

If you've played the first one, this is like that one. Except the charm has been cranked up to eleven, and the difficulty has been cranked up to twelve.

The mechanics feel hugely satisfying. Some improvements over the first game, that I didn't know I needed, were made; such as climbing gloves requiring you to press into the wall to hold on to it, running being the default, ... Moving around feels [i] crisp [/i], and though I wanted to blame the game for many of my deaths, it was just me fatfingering a rope, bomb or jump input where it should have been something else.

I've read that the developers wanted the game to feel much more alive, and, well, they've succeeded. All the small little details and interactions add [i] so [/i], so much. Don't want to spoil any here, obviously, but you don't have to look very far. Just the base camp (entrance cave?) itself is filled to the brim with fantastic little details that makes it ideal to destress a bit after you've died for the hundred-and-sixteenth time -  and all the other times, too. [spoiler] The base camp even 'upgrades' as you progress the game! [/spoiler] [spoiler] And you can pet the dog! [/spoiler] This game is amazing!

But yes, it is [i] hard [/i]. I've not played many games where I felt like I'm doing everything right, just for something I did not account for to end a very deep run. So you learn from your mistake, and try again. But boy, is there a lot to learn.

Overall, this game is beautifully crafted, stupidly difficult, and I think I've ragequit about every other playsession. 10/10

Many reviewers here share the same sentiment:  We thoroughly enjoyed Spelunky HD and felt it was balanced properly, despite being a hard roguelike.  Personally, I'm fine with a challenge.  Sometimes even overly difficult challenges like Real Platinum God on vanilla BoI:  Rebirth.  That being said, the challenge this game presents is just not fun.  Instead of learning from your mistakes and feeling a sense of accomplishment, the game will find new and creative ways to unfairly kill you in the early levels, wasting your time and leaving you frustrated.  Everything is taken from the first game and made slightly worse.  As many others have said, health is effectively useless in this game, because almost always, 1 hit from literally anything that stuns you will lead to your demise, even if only from stunlock.  The game has several things which are straight up unfair, such as ghost pots being broken by the environment shortly into the stage, spawning the ghost (ending your run), or lava physics infinitely pouring down the shaft created by the drill, making the vampire area impossible to reach.  The most recent one that had me closing the game was when an enemy apparently wandered into a shop offscreen, causing the shopkeeper to fire from offscreen and instantly kill me.  It took me a second to realize that those were shotgun pellets, since I didn't even know there was a shop there.  Huh.  Alt+F4.

When many players of your game all share the same negative points in their review, it indicates that your game has a problem, not that the players themselves are the problem.

TLDR:  Instead of upon dying and finding yourself saying saying: "Well, guess I could've avoided that enemy/trap better, let's try again", this game will leave you saying "Well, that ACTUALLY wasn't my fault, but whatever", before closing the game and wisely spending your time elsewhere.

I recently dove into Spelunky 2, and let me tell you, it's less of a game and more of a psychological experiment. Picture this: You start your adventure, all wide-eyed and hopeful, ready to explore caves and unearth treasures. Fast forward ten minutes, and you're face-first in a pit of spikes, questioning every decision you've ever made.

Spelunky 2 is like that friend who insists on telling you a joke that only they find funny, and you're stuck there pretending to laugh while your soul slowly withers away. The difficulty curve is steeper than my grandma's secret pancake recipe, and just as unforgiving.

One thing I've learned is that death in Spelunky 2 is not a setback; it's a lifestyle. It's the only game where my demise is so frequent, I've started treating it as a casual inconvenience. "Oh look, I triggered a trap and got squished by a giant spider again. Classic Tuesday."

The characters in this game are like the cast of a sitcom, each with their quirks and tendencies. I've got my go-to explorer who has a talent for tripping over his own feet, and let's not forget the hired help, who can either save your run or sabotage it with the grace of a drunken llama.

The levels are meticulously designed death traps, and every time I think I've got the hang of it, Spelunky 2 throws a curveball. "Oh, you thought you were safe? Here's a ghost that will make your heart race faster than a cat on a hot tin roof."

Despite the countless deaths and the occasional rage-induced existential crisis, there's something oddly charming about Spelunky 2. It's like the game is challenging me to be a better, more patient person. Or maybe it's just trying to break me. Jury's still out on that one.

In conclusion, Spelunky 2 is not for the faint of heart. If you're looking for a relaxing gaming experience, this is not it. But if you enjoy testing the limits of your sanity and revel in the absurdity of virtual spelunking, then by all means, take the plunge. Just don't say I didn't warn you.
I love it when my friend jumps directly into a spark trap that sends him flying into me, blowing up my jet pack, and killing the eggplant child. Otherwise, good game.

Spelunky 2 is the sequel to the best platform game I've ever played--Spelunky. Spelunky 2 is so good you won't want to go back to Spelunky! The number of enemies, level types, and secrets have been increased and improved on from the first Spelunky. It's so, so fantastic!

Most significant upside: The story and game design are fantastic--even though the levels are randomly generated! The secrets different paths to the end also keep the game interesting!

Most significant downside: How far you get in the game is basically the difficulty level. If you want easy difficulty you won't make it more than 4 levels down; however, if you are OK with challenging yourself you can complete the game--with practice. In other words, this game WILL challenge you.

After that, I decided to delete the game. I'm too afraid to challenge other hidden levels. It's not a game for fun at all. I strongly advise people over 25 not to play it. Spelunky 2 is an incredibly difficult game, much more difficult than its predecessor Spelunky HD. The game will make you rage, a lot, for hours. However, this game is still incredibly fun. With lots of content you'll probably never get to see!
The visuals, levels, enemies, bosses, and almost everything else is an incredible improvement over Spelunky HD, apart from a few things.

That mainly being the music, the music is still very good and is actually dynamic now which is great. There are many amazing tracks you will likely love... however, they all fall short when compared to Spelunky HD. This is likely because that game didn't need to focus on dynamic music and only needed to focus on happy jingles to nod along too.
Another criticism about the game actually stems from 2 new features, that being the back layers and fluid physics. The back layers are a very interesting concept that just isn't used very effectively, with there not being much content or anything interesting to explore there. The other one is fluid physics, while being a great concept, the lava causes more annoyances that great times, blocking level paths and making the drill in volcano slightly more RNG heavy as well as making the game significantly more computer intensive.

Despite this criticism, the game is still amazing and one I heavily implore you to try. While it doesn't have the exact same feel as Spelunky HD you will still have an incredibly, painfully fun time! (Especially, if you enjoyed Spelunky HD.)
The new areas are great to venture through, and you can finally play with your friends online if you can manage the input delay. 

I have completed all achievements and it took me 61.9 hours, the achievements are varied and great and I am almost ready to hang up mining helmet, however I still crave to do one more challenge, that being the endless expanse of pain after those 22 levels of turmoil. You should play the game to understand what I mean, because there is a greater challenge hidden away from the achievements here, one you will likely never complete...

I give this game a solid 9/10 - great gameplay, difficulty and challenges with good but not excellent music. The game is slightly more RNG dependent than the previous game, but this still leaves room for a lot of fun.
Well done to Derek Yu! And remember always to "ransack those shopkeeper's pockets" while Kali watches!

I feel that Spelunky/Spelunky HD basically wrote the book on the modern rouge-like and Spelunky 2 certainly follows in its footsteps, however i feel it has a few stumbles along its path. To be fair, the few issues i have are drops in the bucket compared to what the game does well, but once noticed they never quite go away. 

One annoyance is the world generation, especially for the first area, the Dwelling. World generation in spelunky works on a sort of grid system, with hand created "rooms" being strung together randomly (with a few failsafes to ensure the exit is always reachable), and the ones for Dwelling often result in boring and samey levels with pointless dead ends, sometimes having most of the level not even accessible unless you use one of your precious bombs. Even then there's often nothing worth searching for. This issue is somewhat lessened in other areas, but still very much present, and if your hunting for secrets in a few areas, being constantly cut off from what your looking for and needing a bomb or item to get there is tedious.

Another is the ever known risk of getting "spelunkyed". Often Spelunky 2 is rough but fair, rewarding quick thinking and attention, but sometimes it will place you into true no-win situations due to no fault of your own, or a single slip up will send your battered body flying into multiple enemies and traps then finally into a boiling pool of lava, all with no chance of recovery. In these instance the most you can do is try to marvel at how horribly your life was just ended and try again, but if your luck is bad and the game is placing enemies and traps with no remorse it can get annoying.

One of my last issues involves the new "Background Caves" and the fluid dynamics, but is a bit of a nitpick. The fluid dynamics is mostly just interesting, but with lava you can sometimes end up screwed either by your own actions, or random things just happening around you (this ties in to the concept of getting spelunkyed). Meanwhile the background caves are just sort of... there. often they have nothing of interest, the small ones often having nothing but a bat or two, while the large ones MAY have a special shop. However, the shops include a caveman run shop who sells rocks and skulls more often then not, and while the other shop you can run into often has a few choice items for grabs the actual chances of FINDING the entrance to the back caves is seemingly totally luck based (I have seen nothing online about there being ANY way to reliably find the things if they exit past getting a bit lucky with an exposed entrance, if a way exists i dont know it)

I front-loaded this review with the things that annoyed me, but i think my hours played can attest to what i think of the game overall. If you think you reach the skill floor for this game (I recommend starting out not really caring too much about finding secrets or playing perfect, just start building your skills to see if you can git gud) and are interested in this type of game, I 100% endorse this one and recommend you buy it.

Minimally improved from the previous game, for a sequel it largely fails to add much more to the experience; being heavily recycled conceptually.


The overall presentation remains polished and comfortably stylish, while the gameplay is quite satisfying and engaging to interact with. Unlike the previous game however the story makes absolutely zero sense, and many conceptual elements of the world have been outright recycled for no explicable reason. Which only renders the story even more nonsensical due to said repetition.

Unfortunately many problems from the previous game are still here, and in this regard the system has seen almost no improvement. The game has zero protection against stun-locking and many hazards that will exploit it, numerous hazards that instantly knock the player out regardless of their health, hazards that will instantly strike the player from off-screen or ambush them as they enter a level, hazards hidden behind objects in the foreground, completely random item and resource acquisition that will sometimes deprive the player of crucial gear, mechanics designed to punish the player for certain actions will be triggered by things other than the player, numerous underpowered items that simply are not worth using unless nothing else is available; and more.

The controls are tight and precise but players are randomly put into overbearing situations that require unreasonable split-second levels of finesse to survive. Most of the time the game rewards the player for being reasonably dexterous and obstacles can be overcome through such, but randomly an overbearing situation will arise that requires an instantaneous and completely exact reaction to survive. These situations are so random and specific that players have zero chance of anticipating or learning from them, which makes surviving those encounters even less plausible for any player that does not have literally perfect reactions; or luck. Beyond that certain elements of the controls are entirely contrary to dexterous gameplay. Such as the wall and ledge grabbing mechanics that players cannot fully control or the finicky grab and crawl mechanics.

As the game has many difficult, nuanced obstacles a massive amount of trial and error is needed to memorize how every single thing works just to avoid instantly getting knocked out by a single threat. The game makes an extremely obvious point of punishing players for their lack of knowledge in regards to any conceivable thing. However this game is filled with mechanics that operate in extremely specific yet variable ways that only become more volatile when they happen to randomly be combined with other things. This results in countless hyper-niche situations where players are punished for not knowing the single answer to a rare problem that will never manifest again for potentially dozens of hours in playtime due to sheer randomness. Which actively serves to contradict the act of learning since by the time players actually encounter that threat again, they will potentially have forgotten the one counter that it has.

Every single time the player makes a mistake, is unlucky or gets presented with an unfair obstacle their entire survival hangs in the balance. It is completely random whether a given mishap will knock the player out, or simply wound them. Thus even the act of failing this game is arbitrary. Sometimes the player will make one mistake during the course of an hour long run and survive, other times they will be completely obliterated. The exact same applies to luck and unfair obstacles, like those mentioned above.



The design of this experience is so incoherent that it simultaneously has zero tolerance for mistakes while absolutely rewarding dexterity and memorization but also randomly forgives mistakes while producing obstacles that explicitly undermine dexterity and memorization. Resulting in an experience that, while appealing in its presentation and satisfying in its gameplay, ultimately comes down to random chance when it comes to whether the player actually survives a run or not.

Players do not beat Spelunky or Spelunky Two, Spelunky and Spelunky Two allow players to beat them; randomly. These games have all the tools necessary to guarantee the demise of the player in numerous moments throughout the course of a run. Whether that happens is just entirely random, which is ultimately the result of incompetent balancing.

If you enjoyed and spent a lot of time with the first Spelunky, then this game gets a thumbs up. The new areas are fun to explore, the mechanics have expanded without invalidating your pre-existing knowledge, and the co-op mode is a hilarious romp. But if you're unfamiliar with Spelunky and want to buy a new game, then Spelunky HD might be a better choice.

Given Spelunky 2's similarities to the originals, it's hard not to compare its messiness against what came before it. Both the freeware version of Spelunky 1 and the HD remake emphasized gradual learning and adaptation. Spelunky 2's additions to that formula are mountable animals, flowing water and lava, mechanical switches, layered levels, and a slew of new enemies. While seeing these things in a familiar game is novel, they don't mesh very well with what was already there. The new creatures and the physics elements primarily just contribute random explosions (and deaths) that are out of your control. The sequel’s overall difficulty curve is also backwards, with a brutally-punishing first area that leads into more manageable later levels. 

Spelunky 2 seems like an ambitious fan mod rather than an official sequel, full of lovely details and ridiculous ideas but lacking in direction, vision, and playtesting. It’s not as elegant or as thoughtfully-designed as the first game, so I would only recommend it if you specifically want a steep challenge or online co-op.

I am a 49 yo mother, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single mother to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just, watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. loaded into the game, made my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you were supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he helped me. Loved it as it was the best time had spent with my Son since my husband had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

The most satisfying gameplay that, unless you can foresee the future, will still make you want to throw your controller.

"Spelunky 2" is a roguelike in its textbook definition: procedurally generated levels, restart fully every time you die, knowledge is the only power-up you can carry over to a new run.
The story is a minor element of the game. There is enough lore to come up with a comprehensive world, but the universe is not fully explained outside of some retreads from the first game.
What took me so long to consider the game "completed" is that there are multiple endings. The first two are quite straightforward and reward you with achievements, the other one is a long, LONG challenge for those who are willing to take on it. Don't let your inner completionist prevent you from having fun.
The gameplay is the highlight of the game: the movement is extremely fluid, terraforming allows the player to manipulate levels in multiple ways… and there's also RNG. You will get frustrated from falling particles, bad events outside your control, and sometimes even unpleasant level generation with countless traps.
"Spelunky 2" offers cross-platform multiplayer and arena modes, but I haven't experimented with them much. If it sounds like your jam — prepare for co-op shenanigans.

You will lose your patience with this game… and it's going to be glorious. Have fun in whatever way you'll choose.

Going forward, I would like let the reader know that this comprehensive review of Spelunky 3 will contain spoilers.

Hello everyone, I am here to give you my thorough review on the electronic entertainment application that is Spelunky 2!

One of the fundamental things I would like to say about this electronic entertainment application is that it can be a very frustrating experience to start off with. I would, however like to stress that this frustration does not last as you will find yourself immersed in the never ending, never the same, side-winding caves that make up the fabric of this very game.

Another thing I would like to say about this video game is that losing to the game is a core part of the learning experience, and the main reason I do not play this game any more. There are plenty of players in Spelunky 2 which have completed the 7-99 challenge which is referred to as the highest accomplishment in this game! I am not one of these people and if you can see by the amount of time I have played this game, it's a rather sorry ordeal. Do not let this put you off from trying to beat the 7-99 challenge yourself though!

The core gameplay loop of Spelunky 2 offers a wide range of choices when it comes to your approach to how you play the game. You can choose to be fast and get the best time on the leaderboards or you can play slow and methodical to try and achieve a high score. The lightning-fast response time coded into the games mechanics offers a clean, consistent and fun game experience. The ways in which you can tackle each obstacle presented to you in a given level are almost limitless.

The art style of the game presents itself as an easy to look at, easy to understand interface in which you can decipher where you are in the game world with little to no effort. The jovial and childlike elements to the approach on the art side of things makes this game very accessible to all demographics of people.

The sound design present in Spelunky 4 is pleasant at times and at other times, leaves a lot to be desired. The soundtracks in this game are well composed, as the artists behind the soundtrack in Spelunky 6 is also the same one in Spelunky 3.
Eirik Suhrke's music is some of my favourite video game music in the original Spelunky, however I feel that due to the more atmospheric and ambient approach to the soundtrack in the new game, it lacks a certain charm which was found in Spelunky HD.

In conclusion I would like to say that this game is one of the games of all time. Spelunky 2 presents itself as one of the most challenging games of all time while also not taking itself too seriously. The developer himself, Derek Yu, maintains the viewpoint that this game is akin to that of a permanent learning experience where every death within the game is part of the game play loop, seeing which new wacky and funny way to die, one after the other.

If you are a person who enjoys a fun and casual experience, you should try this game because you will realise when you are not having fun anymore, you'll stop, like a normal person. However if you are a masochist you won't stop, and you'll continue to play the game for almost 1000 hours like me, all the while having nothing to show for it.

Thank you for reading my comprehensive review on Spelunky 2077.

Spelunky 2 is the gold standard for roguelike platformers. Despite the light-hearted theme, Spelunky 2 is seriously challenging in all the rights ways. After 140 hours and hundreds of runs, I feel like I’ve been on an expansive and fulfilling journey. Not only an in-game journey, exploring new levels, finding cool items, etc. but also a personal journey in which I had to overcome both mental and physical hurdles to get to where I’m at today. Defeating Hundun has to be one of my favorite accomplishments in gaming and one that will mark the end of a journey that I barely thought possible. But who knows, maybe I’ll come back and reach 7-99 someday. After coming this far, I can’t rule it out.

Spelunky 2 is an extremely fun "sequel" to an already very fun game. They took the formula of spelunky 1 and expanded on it in probably the best way possible. All the traps and enemies are still just as lethal as in its predecessor, and discovering all the secrets is quite fun, if a bit annoying at times. There are situations where you have to carry a specific item across a lot of areas, so it becomes quite frustrating when you have a good run going, only for you to be squished by a floating block. 
But it is still very much a high skill-ceiling game, so you will feel yourself getting better at it, and it feels so [b] good [/b] once you manage pull off the thing you wanted to.

Now for the coop, oh boy the coop. The coop is the reason why I even decided to write a review. it is so incredibly fun and chaotic, especially if it's late in the evening or you are getting drunk together with your friends. All the different chain reactions that are already common during single player, get amplified by however many friends you bring with you. Arena mode is also incredibly fun if you want to have a quick smackdown at your friends. some of the maps are so chaotic, that at some point it becomes impossible to figure out what is happening, but that is the whole fun of it.

Anyways game good, go buy it now.

If you don't mind true unfairness, RNG elements, and unreadable chaos in your skill-based platformer rogue-like, you might be able to tolerate this game, and even appreciate it, just know that no matter how good you are, you physically won't be able to predict and avoid some of the stuff that can happen in this game, it is basically a core tenet of how this game was designed and can be felt throughout the entire experience. I personally absolutely despise playing this game, but I have a lot of respect for the solid and single-minded design choices throughout it, the main creator of the game, Derek Yu, really knew what kind of game he wanted to make, and as a result, this game feels consistent and coherent from beginning to the end... Even if that makes you consistently hate playing it, like I do.

In the realm of video games, where innovation and creativity thrive, Spelunky 2 emerges as a captivating masterpiece that invites players into a world of endless exploration and exhilarating challenges. From the very first descent into its underground depths, players are swept away by the sheer joy and excitement that the game exudes.

The core gameplay of Spelunky 2 centers around procedural generation, creating a new adventure with each playthrough. As players navigate through treacherous environments filled with traps, enemies, and hidden secrets, they're constantly kept on their toes, anticipating the unexpected. This unpredictability ensures that every run is a fresh experience, encouraging players to adapt and improvise their strategies.

The pixel art style of Spelunky 2 is a nostalgic homage to classic gaming while embracing modern intricacies. The charming and detailed visuals breathe life into the world, making every environment brim with personality and mystery. From lush jungles to eerie temples, each area tells a story of its own, enticing players to delve deeper and uncover its secrets.

The heart of Spelunky 2's appeal lies in its challenging gameplay. Death is a constant companion, but every defeat only serves to motivate players to improve. The sense of accomplishment that accompanies conquering a difficult obstacle or defeating a challenging boss is truly unparalleled, rewarding players for their determination and skill.

The game's myriad of interconnected systems creates a web of possibilities, encouraging experimentation and creativity. The variety of items, weapons, and power-ups add depth to the gameplay, allowing players to forge their own paths and discover unique strategies. Whether it's navigating treacherous terrain or battling formidable foes, every decision counts, making every moment an engaging puzzle to solve.

Spelunky 2's multiplayer mode amplifies the fun. Friends can join forces to explore the depths together, adding an extra layer of camaraderie and cooperation. The shared experience of triumphs and failures fosters a sense of togetherness, and the chaotic yet enjoyable nature of multiplayer only enhances the game's appeal.

The game's atmospheric soundtrack is a symphony of adventure, underscoring every jump, swing, and encounter. The music seamlessly adapts to the changing situations, heightening the tension during challenging moments and celebrating victories with triumphant melodies. The audio design serves as a captivating companion to the visual spectacle.

Spelunky 2's fusion of challenging gameplay, captivating artistry, and boundless exploration culminates in an experience that is as fun as it is rewarding. The game's ability to create memorable stories within its procedurally generated world ensures that each playthrough is a unique adventure. In a landscape filled with sprawling open worlds and epic narratives, Spelunky 2 stands tall as a testament to the enduring appeal of tightly designed, challenging gameplay that leaves players hungry for one more run.

Would not recommend. The biggest issue - this game feels like it expects more out of its players than its devs are willing to put in.

This is for many reasons. Spelunky HD was punishing, and technically has its own issues, but after wrapping your head around it, Spelunky HD becomes very completable in a campy way (learning [spoiler]that you always should go for the worm sword if you're doing a secret route run, and figuring out how to game the pathing on the ghosts to generate enough money to complete a secret run without too much RNG.[/spoiler]). Also, Spelunky HD had multiple soundtracks that would generate for each level. Not so here.

Spelunky HD's level design felt experimental, Spelunky 2's level design feels at times bloated, sometimes bad. With Spelunky HD, the [spoiler]mothership level is pretty much worthless except for very specific things, but it's a single stage that's easy to ignore.[/spoiler] With Spelunky 2 they throw in [spoiler]an entire temple world which is more difficult than the other world options, with no better rewards--but they do this sometime after giving a world selection choice in the same style that is actually meaningful[/spoiler]. Including the [spoiler] temple world [/spoiler], as it is, is touted like a feature, rather than an ugly piece of game design that should have been heavily reworked as soon as playtesting was underway.

The official devs have made excuse threads on Reddit about why there isn't a chat feature in multiplayer, trying to convince others to use their official discord as a 3rd party tool for communication on their game, and this is a problem. Why might a chat feature be important? Here's a very real example; if you use random lobbies to try and see more of the game for yourself than you could solo, eventually you'll get to some secret stuff, specifically with [spoiler] one room in the final world where a giant countdown may appear. This happens when at least one of the players initiates a boss rush, for extra HP. If you make the mistake of thinking that you need to leave before the numbers reach zero, you will be ~permanently hated by your lobby[/spoiler]. The ability to shoot off emoticons, and/or specific other messages, perhaps only unlocked after entering World 3 (to prevent spam and redundancy, the early levels should become muscle memory) would have been nice idea, but we do not have this here.

If you complete a multiplayer game in the style mentioned above, you will not receive the ending achievement. It would be nice if there was a multiplayer-specific separate achievement that the game could award, for seeing the ending this way - it would encourage this playstyle (using multiplayer with experienced players to figure out the levels). You could even build on this idea by giving out achievements to seasoned players for showing new players new sections of the map (would encourage participation in random lobbies). No such luck. Spelunky HD had an issue of not giving out incremental achievements for items between the normal and hard runs of the game, this issue is compounded here. INB4 "of course the game doesn't have to give you anything for *several* hours of your time if you don't win, it's a roguelike," plenty of other roguelikes give you *something* for your work.

Derek Yu would rather embark on book tours about how he reinvented game design than he would dedicate himself to crafting the perfect game. Spelunky HD was lightning in a bottle. This game is absolutely worth it. I would not say it is the most "fun" i've had, but it is definitely infinitely entertaining. This is a game, perfect for those with a limited temperament who want a challenge (you WILL be infuriated). The roguelike genre of the game gives it infinite replay-ability, and since every round is pretty short, unless you're a god at the game, dying just takes you back a few minutes, and therefore you don't really lose anything by dying. Hours fly by in an instant as your brain plays an infinite chorus of "one more round". Have had it for 3 days, and can, after 13 hours of playing, say that it is already more fun when you've played a while. This would be because the game is entirely skill based; everything is always random, therefore nothing is really. Buy it if you think you'll like it, you probably will.

Despite its difficulty, Spelunky 2 is a marvel of both platforms and roguelikes. While it is tough as nails, it feels fair and lessons can be taken from each and every death. All the zones are distinct and fun while still being extremely challenging for most players. Having a game this tough still be this fun and hilarious to play with friends is extremely challenging. Highly recommended for those looking for a tough-as-nails platformer experience without it feeling super unfair.

7+
(depending on gaming skills, mainly)

Gameplay: Exceptional
Spelunky 2 is a rogue-like indie side-scroller and platformer. Each level is randomised, and belongs to an area which defines its enemies, hazards, merits and appearance. It has amazing replay value and multiplayer (Co-op and PVP). Gameplay is frustrating and quite difficult, but nonetheless very enjoyable.

Graphics: Nice
Spelunky 2 has unique, stylised graphics. They are not beautiful, but they are above passable and contribute to the overall atmosphere of the game.

Audio: Also Nice
The soundtrack is very good, not as good as Spelunky HD but nonetheless acceptable. It also matches the game well.

Plot: Satisfactory
Nearly all items, areas, characters and bosses have a degree of lore. Lore is not rich, but it is funny and fairly consistent (rarely seems clunky or patchy). Most characters have an actual legitimate reason to be in the mines. Spelunky 2 retains original lore, though it is greatly expanded upon.

Themes: Very Mild
Includes animated blood droplets and a Hindu goddess (Kali) that you can sacrifice things to. You can kill things like snakes and bats. Shop keepers are capable of being robbed as well as dying (and yes, being killed), though the second two can be hard to achieve. Barely any dark themes. Watch the intro, anything you might consider inappropriate would most likely be featured in it.

Very well done game, still reminiscent of the original but both expanded and refined.

Spelunky 2 is the sequel to the cult classic, critically acclaimed Spelunky. Spelunky 2 takes the difficulty that the first game was known for and ramps it up to its hypothetical limit. This game will test your patience & YOUR GAMER INSTINCTS as you get pummeled to death in hilarious and soul crushing ways.

The concept is easy enough to learn but hard to master, as you die countless times learning new strategies and learning what enemies and traps can instantly kill you and how to work around those. The variety of enemies, level generation, randomized encounters/treasures leaves the levels and gameplay feeling fresh each new run. 

If you like games that challenge you or are a masochist this game will definitely crush your soul in all the right ways lol

The game has a lot of gameplay mechanics and concepts that make it very fun. The gold and gems, shopkeepers, bombs and items, physics, the dynamic procedurally generated levels are addictive and make you want to keep coming back to play. Co-op multiplayer both couch and online works well, and I can have a lot of fun playing with friends. However, over a broad time period of playing the game, the negatives seems to always outweigh the positives, and I end up getting frustrated and wonder why I keep playing. My problem with the game is really only in two areas which if fixed would make the game a lot more fair and a lot more fun. I don't mind difficulty, and I don't mind instant deaths, but for a game to be fun it should have good controls and be fair. 

1) The controls are terrible. 1/3 of the things you do in this game end up being accidental because of horrible controls. 
A) Player movement is extremely clunky and not analog. Why is a game designed for modern consoles in 2020 using a control scheme of digital pad with hold R to go faster? If the developers only want to have 2 movement speeds, just let the Joystick slightly pressed be 1 speed and joypad 50% or further be the running speed. I don't understand why they have to make the game so clunky and uncontrollable where holding and unholding R just to get the correct speed is required to do basic things... (one speed is useless to get over obstacles, but is uncontrollable in close combat, making you unnecessarily run into enemies and spikes). Mario for SNES in 1983 had better controls. 
B) Throwing items is a complete crapshoot and half the time you have no idea where the thing you are throwing is going to land. Up throw, hit the ceiling riccochet off and kills you. Throw standing still, flies super far and over the thing you're aiming at. Throw down, flies too far to the right. Basic bomb, flies through enemies and way too far behind blowing up a shop keeper in a room you can't even see. Some items fly in a forward arc, some items fly diagonally and up to the right even when holding right. Why would you make the game so frustrating? Again even Mario from 1983 had predictable throw patterns that made the game skill based and fun to play, not random and causing game ending accidents that are 100% due to shitty controls. 
C) Who the hell would ever come up with a gameplay mechanic that punishes the player and makes them drop the item they are carrying if you stand near an edge for a few seconds? Easy answer: a developer who is trying to piss people off. 
D) Why does the whip have to have a .5 second delay to hit???? This mechanic is so stupid and frustrating to no end. A basic enemy can hit you if it appears before your stupid whip has enough time to hit them. 

2) Fix the stun bullshit in this game!! It makes zero sense that enemies stunned can't be hurt, but you can get stunlocked by enemies and chain hit with no way to struggle, and press buttons or move the joystick to wake up. Pick one or the other! Stun while hit or invincibility while stunned. The best option would be to just remove the stupid stun mechanic completely from the game. It's so stupid and frustrating for a platformer standing there waiting for enemies to wake up for 5 seconds to have to jump on them 3 times because if you pick them up they wake up and hit you in less than a second.

Spelunky 2, my honest review.

This game is incredible. To start, it feels extremely polished, extremely finished, and doesn't feel like there would be any bugs. Though there are some bugs that happen *very* infrequently, they still don't change the playing experience.

..the playing experience, though...

This game is BRUTAL. Easily one of the hardest games ever made. After 315 hours of learning the games mechanics, how everything works, and being able to come up with scenarios in my head of how things will interact (and 99% of the time being correct), I am still finding new ways to die, some of them especially feel extremely unfair. I genuinely love this game though, its such a fun time (when youre not being loopkilled by shopkeepers or getting bullshitted in CO) when I'm playing it. The achievements have a nice challenge to them, and they definitely are extremely rewarding when you get them, especially The Full Spelunky.

The music and artstyle of this game is impeccable. I absolutely love the art in this game, from characters to enemies to bosses, all of them look incredible. The music is no different, it completely fits every place in the game, and the way it works in the files is very interesting, including the fluidity of the tracks.

This game is a solid 10/10. No question. The unfairness is only unfair for a small amount of time, you begin to learn how everything works, and you realize "oh, I could have done this to prevent that from happening," and next time something like that happens, it feels good to have dodged it. This game is perfect, if not it is the closest game to it.

Final comments, I hate Dwellings, LISE Project my beloved, and fuck you Crocmen.

Just like Spelunky HD, but with more content, improvements and deaths!

Spelunky 2 is a roguelike platformer, a very challenging one at that.

You make your way through different areas, each containing various deadly traps and enemies that can end your run in an instant if you're not careful or prepared. Every death can be frustrating, especially when it happens out of nowhere (Spelunky moment) but with knowledge and new discoveries comes confidence. What might have made you panic or anxious before, not knowing how to overcome it, is now only just a small problem in a bunch of other complications.

The improvements are quite nice, like better graphics, more precise movement and local/online multiplayer (Co-op/PvP).
Though if you're going for 100% completion you probably will be playing alone most of the time since a lot of the achievements require you to play non-seeded singleplayer runs.

It is an unforgiving game that will actively try to kill and break you, but once you know everything and are confident enough it will become a rewarding experience.

Spelunky 2 is a great game. It can also be fun to play with friends!

You travel through different areas each with unique graphic and game-play styles. You can defeat bosses and there are [spoiler]multiple endings and secret areas[/spoiler]. You can also find, purchase or steal resources and items to help you with your journey.

It also has many improvements over Spelunky (HD).
Like better graphics, easier movement, a more expansive world and [b]multiplayer![/b] (online co-op/PvP)
Some things that were better in Spelunky (HD) were subjectively the music, the Kali sacrificing graphics, the Jungle's (area) atmosphere and somehow the feeling of nostalgia.

The online co-op with [u]random[/u] players can be a bit glitchy because of the online connection, but it's still playable. Though it can turn chaotic with players not always agreeing.

If you are playing through Steam though the online co-op connection is in my experience usually good.

Also you can play Arena which is a PvP game-mode but at time of writing this review not with random players. Only with bots or through Steam basically. This is probably because it would be even more chaotic than random online co-op due to the same elements mentioned above.

TLDR: Try this game and don't let what people say dissuade you.

People are afraid of Spelunky; thinking it's too hard, too luck-based, too bullshit, too scary, etc. From playing this game as much as I have, I can understand why people think that. However, I also believe that those people could not be more wrong. This game is fun at every turn. It's always new, always exciting, always entertaining, and the engine it runs in allows for an endless amount of creativity and ease. Movement feels very precise and smooth. Enemies feel very balanced and are fun to interact with. The game will present you with puzzles with multiple solutions and you, as the player, can decide which routes to take to solve them. Just watch Twiggle (May he rest in peace. He will always be one of the most iconic and influential people this community will ever see.) on YouTube and tell me you don't want to try this game for yourself!

spunky 2

Spelunky was a classic.  Many people found it frustrating, but it didn't require lightly reflexes to enjoy, just a bit of a mindset adjustment and a little persistence.  The excellent procedural generation encouraged persistence.  A "mere mortal" gamer could certainly get to level 13 or 14 (more than half way through).

Spelunky 2 ruins that finely balanced difficulty curve by giving you 4 too-easy levels followed by an impossible 5th.  Also an odd choice, the 4th level isn't procedurally generated, making it a bit of a grind after 5 or 10 games.

If you're a superhuman who can speedrun Spelunky 1 then this review doesn't apply to you.  Otherwise, give Spelunky 2 a miss (and go play the original classic!)

When Zelda: Breath of the Wild was released, much was said about how the mechanics and systems in the game made it feel like a living, breathing world.
Spelunky 2 has a similar level of detail, only it feels more like the goal of developer, Derek Yu, was to turn the interactions between the world, the monsters, the traps and the items you can pick up into a Rube Goldberg machine that wants to kill you in the most hilarious way possible.

Art, music, sound, everything is amazing. It's a triumph of design, and an absolute joy to play. I'd strongly recommend reading as little about the game as possible, and playing and learning as you go - it's an intensely satisfying experience to test out different items in different situations just to find a little bit more about the caves yourself.

Already an almost perfect game, which can only get better once the promised co-op update finally gets re-launched!
