Masterpiece.

It is a very difficult game, but for some reason, it is not frustrating. I believe the reason is because you have an incredible amount of agency over yourself and your surroundings, so when you inevitably die, it is typically due to a miss-input, a genuine mistake, lack of planning, cautiousness or awareness. These are things you can learn from and improve on your next run. Restarting is fast too, so sitting through load times is a non-existent problem.

Level design is top-notch. The randomly generated levels are still filled with mystery and don't ever seem to get old or feel samey from run-to-run.

Music and sound effects are perfect.

Multiplayer makes this already great game even better, as playing with friends always makes every experience more fun.

Overall, 10/10. Worth full price. Only warning is that it is very difficult, so if you're the type to like easy-breezy games, this won't be for you.

PS: after beating the game, I will say: this game does contain nonsense, especially at the later levels. There will be traps that are impossible to see coming that will instant kill you, in certain setups. Also, a really annoying gripe i have with the game is that many of their secrets can only be found coincidentally or by finding the answer online. As someone who likes discovering secrets, I find it incredibly annoying that there are no hints or clues that would push you to try certain things. Again, this isn't all secrets, as some do have clues and nudges. I'd say, about 35% of the secrets have no hint that they exist. Otherwise, still a good game.

[h1]Spelunky 2 - Not My Kind of Game[/h1]

I understand, and appreciate what the game is about.  It's very challenging, and was made to be challenging which harkens back to the old school 8-bit/16-bit games.  However, the difficulty in some of those games were due to technical limitations, poor design choices, port from an arcade game trying to screw you out of quarters, or other issues.

I am [u]not a fan of rage games[/u] like these so please be aware of that when seeing my recommendation and review.  

In terms of positives and why I got this game?  Simple!  For the co-op play.  I found the co-op with friends to be [u]so much fun at first[/u].  Going through the challenges and running around was a blast!  Graphically this games is great.  The art style is easy on the eye, and overall very smooth on my increasingly aging computer.  I am of the belief games with art style such as Spelunky 2 will age better than those who go for realism.  Especially since technology is so fast and realism dates itself quickly. 

What I distinctly didn't like about the game [i][b](keep in mind I hadn't played since Jan of 2021 so this info may be out of date as of this writing)[/b][/i] was the fact that once you lost all your lives you start at the [b]very beginning[/b].  We'd reach level 2-1, lose all our lives, and start at level 1-1 all over again.  At first it's funny but, after the 10th time playing with 2 other people of various skill level [i](me probably being the worst one)[/i] it quickly loses its appeal.  The 8-bit era had memory issues hence why progress couldn't be saved in some games.  We don't have those issues today for games. So not being able to save my progress showed how little patience I had.

Another issue?  One hit deaths or worst - fall deaths on blind corners / platforms.  The stages were procedurally generated so this meant you can die in the most tragic, unlucky way.

Like I said just not my kind of game.

[b]Pros:[/b]

+ Fantastic artwork, and style
+ Co-op mode
+ Simple gameplay mechanics and controls

[b]Cons:[/b]

- One hit deaths, no continues, and no saving progress
- Frustrating gameplay (which many may see as a positive)
- Very difficult
- Having start all over again once you lose all your lives

[b]Recommend:[/b] Not a fan of this frustrating, "git gud" type of game
[b]If you need a rating out of 10:[/b] 4 /10

A shop owner shoots you for no discernible reason and the whole of his inventory explodes.

The harder it hits me, the more I go bacl.

The parts that generate are really tricky sometimes, but absolutely a fun time to explore

EDIT: I've now played the game for almost 1000 hours, gotten all the achievements, and beat the hardest challenge the game has to offer. I still highly recommend this game. I just want to touch on a few more things.

A lot of the negative reviews that you'll see will label the deaths as unfair. I agree! Some really do seem unfair.  The point is, you can catch on to how not to put yourself into those kinds of situations in the first place. Got unfairly hit by an arrow trap at the edge of the screen into a bed of spikes? Whoops, that's a thing in Spelunky! If it really concerns you, you can walk slower across the platform while staying aware, or throw things in front of you to potentially trigger it. Is there too much lava in the volcano world when you trigger the drill? Maybe the volcano level seems easy at first but has its downsides, and you might get some of the benefits by going to the jungle instead, or figuring out some work-around. That's why there are 2 world choices, it's built to have some downsides and you just have to judge for yourself what you want to do. The world of Spelunky is absolutely cruel and unforgiving, I agree, but the point isn't for everything to have an "Oh, if only I just-" answer, sometimes it's just "Don't even touch situations like that unless I can bomb it or change something about it". Even in Spelunky death compilations online, you can look at the footage and about 80% of the time be able to say something like "Oh, he got telefragged by a croc-man after the cobra spit onto it and damaged it? Maybe I shouldn't be horizontally aligned with a croc man and a cobra next to each other." You really can learn quite a bit. Also honestly, if it's a bit daunting at first, I would honestly recommend starting with the $15 Spelunky title. I think there were more conventionally fair deaths in that game than in this game, and it's much easier (but still tough as nails) to 100% that game. 

This game is seriously very good. The controls are extremely responsive, the world is incredibly fleshed out with interesting things and secrets, only made better by the level generation, and it's an absolute blast to play this with friends. Maybe if you're struggling to get by, like I previously mentioned, this may also be an option? (Just a note, you don't have to share a screen in online multiplayer, so in my opinion it's much better than local if you have somebody else that owns the game). Seriously, this game is worth way more than $20. The interactions between all the different elements in the game make for insanely fun and interesting moments, stories to tell, memories to make, and the more you play the more you'll find that that's absolutely by design. (Or if you listen to any interviews about the game's design by the creator, he'll just tell you that it's his design for the game.)

I want to like this game. I really do. But as it is, I don't think I can recommend it for the average player.

Simply put, this game is difficult. However, it's not the good type of difficult. Anyone who knows me knows that I love challenging experiences, such as Dark Souls, or Dead Cells, and most other roguelikes. I love to bash my head against a wall again, and again, and again, until eventually the wall begins to crack and I have permanent brain damage from excessive head trauma.

But Spelunky 2 does not embody that type of difficulty. A majority of your deaths will feel unfair, because things you have no way of seeing or knowing will pop out of nowhere, stun you and knock you into insta-kill traps. I think this would be fine, but I'll make another comparison to Dark Souls in terms of difficulty: in Dark Souls, almost every death will feel like your fault, and as you die, you'll learn how to deal with whatever it is that murdered you. A skeleton will cut you up, so you learn to block or roll around it and stab it first. In Spelunky 2, practically every death is the opposite - it rarely feels like your own fault. A cave mole will pop up right underneath you, stun you, and launch you into spikes. You'll try to navigate a ledge, only for a skull you weren't able to see to spawn a skeleton, stun you, and launch you off the ledge to your death.

It's just not as fun as it could be, because it rarely feels like your own fault, and it's a damn shame because the game looks great, and otherwise plays great.

Ultimately, it's not something I can recommend for most. If you read this and think "wow, this sounds amazing", then great, I'm happy for you and the enjoyment you might get from it. But for me, seeing the first level 100+ times isn't fun. I enjoy excessive punishment, but not like this.

With every attempt to play this game, with every simple death I've encountered, with every enemy that only takes one or two actions to kill, and with every desire to play it again, I get caught in a cycle again and again. The type of psychology I encountered interfered greatly with my desire to continue playing this addictive game, and it's pretty hard to endure the Game Over screen. That particular little aspect when you see your dead body and think to yourself that you have finally learned the lesson on how to get around this mistake, you keep making mistakes after that, even if you have already experienced them. You keep promising that I'll never do it again. This game really tests your resolve and your own knowledge of whether you can win this game or rather get close to the end. I highly recommend it if you want to know what it's like to be decisive when you're in a frenzy and exciting situation.

Is this a worthy sequel to Spelunky? 

NO, NOPE, NO WAY

Sure, it adds a whole bunch of new visuals and general stuff, -what you might expect from a mere expansion pack perhaps, it does not improve on or fix anything that was wrong with the original game.

-Difficulty is way, way up
-many things now feel deeply "unfair" in ways that the old game didn't
-shopkeepers (and now other NPCs, yay) are still ridiculously op, and can be turned forever hostile by monsters rather than the player
-the whip seems to have a smaller hitbox, and doesn't seem to whip above or behind at all like it used to
-the rope doesn't seem to harm enemies like it used to
-enemies still can have multiple HP, and cannot be hurt while they are stunned, worse, there are more multiple HP enemies, and they're harder than ever.
-meanwhile, YOU can still be hit any time, and can still take damage while stunned, meaning that stunlock issues haven't been fixed since the last game.

Don't let the improved visuals fool you, this game is less polished than the first one, not more. This is not a sequel, more of a collection of new content stapled together.

An extremely solid roguelike platformer, with gameplay randomness that can feel like every run is completely different from another, yet generates consistently fair levels such that you can always improve with every run. There's very rarely any moments where it feels like you died because of the game being unfair instead of your own ignorance, which seems surprisingly rare in roguelikes. You just have to be prepared that every single one of your actions could lead to your death.

It's been over a year, I love this game.
An incredible, more accessible sequel, that is somehow worse than the original but it is better than the first game. What I love about Spelunky HD is the progression, it's the only roguelike where the journey is more satisfying than the conclusion and the game almost feels aware of that. The game creates a pace where it begs you, enrages you, to go faster, but on the other hand, go too slow and you'll be chased by a ghost that kills you when you touch it, but rewards you if you manipulate its movement. It's that moment when you strike that perfect medium of pacing, you absorb the randomly generated environment; the soundtrack, seamlessly being woven together to create this incredible atmosphere, that's when you can truly appreciate Spelunky. But what truly makes the game perfect, is the ability to say fuck that and teleport your way to the end because you have the freedom (and clearly the skill) to do so.

Spelunky 2 on the other hand is like: dun dun bwaooooo bwaooo bwaooooo. The soundtrack more bombastic. The environments, more ambitious. The platforming, more noticeable. The gameplay, has more variety. It wants to be different from HD while still being familiar, but I don't want to veer away from the issues I have at the moment. The way the visuals are designed make each block look separate, as if there is a grid displayed at all times so you know what block you're on, It's kind of like if grass blocks were stacked on top of each other in Minecraft but they didn't turn into dirt blocks. If each block was seamlessly sewn together to create more natural looking environments it would be perfect, and would definitely compliment the dynamic lava graphix, visually. But to be fair, it doesn't have HD in the title so I'll give it the benefit of the doubt. Aside from the visuals, I haven't actually beaten the game yet, I've only ever made it to 7-98.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

If you expected this to improve on the first Spelunky in any way shape or form, think again. It's nearly identical except in the worst ways. Even more frustrating and unfair enemies than in the first. Do you like spawning in on 1-1 and immediately being juggled to death between a lizard and mole? Me neither. The RNG and chaotic gameplay narrowly evades being fun and instead becomes frustrating and pointless.

It's just too hard. There's too many pixel perfect jumps, too many times the random level generators put you in horrendously unfair situations, and despite giving you hit points there's too god damned many instant kill traps and tricks that will end your run again and again and again. Everything has to randomly fall perfectly in line, and then you have to have perfect play if you want to get past the first couple levels. Then you get to be smashed by Olmec, or blown up by Olmec, or stunned and then smashed by Olmec.

It's just not worth it. Go play Metroid.

While there are a lot of things that I do like about this game, there are just too many things that I don't like about this game to actually give it a thumbs up recommendation. For one thing there isn't a ton that differentiates it from its predecessor, the stuff that was added feels pretty inconsequential and are mostly in service of making the game harder than its predecessor, and while there's nothing inherently wrong with wanting to make the game harder, the way that Spelunky 2 was made harder wasn't an improvement in my eyes. 

The original Spelunky is a hard game, but it was hard in a way that made you feel like the fault of dying was your own and that you could overcome the game by learning more about it, cheap deaths were rare and the difficulty was more satisfying, but Spelunky 2 doesn't feel like that, there are a lot more cheap deaths and a lot more instances where you feel like you were put in a situation where there was nothing you could have done differently that wouldn't have resulted in your death, there were a lot more cheap deaths.

Spelunky 2 is also missing some key usability features. In the original Spelunky upon start up you had a quick start option which would start the game using your last used setting, and allowed you to skip all the menus and other stuff and get playing right away. Spelunky 2 doesn't have this, so you are forced to go through the menus each time even if there is nothing you are changing from the last time you played it.

To me, there just isn't enough of an improvement over Spelunky to really recommend Spelunky 2, and in some aspects it feels like a downgrade. If the only thing you were looking for was a more difficult Spelunky then you've got a new game, but for everyone else, just stick with Spelunky.

Spelunky's difficulty is like if you opened the door to a party you were invited into but it turned out that it was a kung fu party. You have to fight yourself in past the first person who guards the door and as you go deeper into the party each new person is more and more difficult to beat. Anyway the first time you lose at the door and you get kicked out and you're like man this party sucks I'll never learn kung fu. But then you go back every single day and you make it a little further into the party. But the door guy still beats you sometimes. But you learn to use the party itself as a vehicle for kung fu; In the exploding balloons, you learn to breathe in the helium to power your shrill scream ability, partygoers can be lured into glitter bombs that the party owner set, and you begin to find stray nachos and cookies after learning how to look. Finally, you get to the kung fu master at the end and she beats you senseless and she says "I hope you enjoyed the party" and you say "yes, I'll beat you next time and I'll truly know kung fu" and she smiles and one day you beat her and she says "You have done well, this party is truly rockin." And you look her in the eye and hold up the invitation crafted from six scattered golden invitations pieces, all scattered around behind the most notorious of her students, and you say "take me to the afterparty" and her eyes go black and she says "Your kung fu has become strong. But can you beat the dreaming master of parties?"

Do you hate yourself? Yes? Then get spelunky 2. Do you want to hate your friends? Well guess what there's an online mode, and I'm not talking about Arenas.(Unit I swear to fucking god why did you grab a fucking wooden totem when I said Smiling Gold and bat.)

A masterpiece just like the first Spelunky but greatly expanded upon with new items, levels, and most importantly secrets. Spelunky 2 is a masterclass in excellent game design and the amount of depth that Derek Yu and Mossmouth have crafted into one game is unprecedented and I can't wait to dive deeper into the content of this game and I feel as though I have only scratched the surface of what there is in this game with mindblowing secrets that are sure to lurk around every corner. It is also much more difficult than the first Spelunky but it rarely feels downright unfair and conquering this game for the first time after only 774 deaths felt amazing. Spelunky 2 was truly incredible and my only real issue is the delay of online coop which was a big feature that disappointedly didn't come out on launch. But apart from that issue, Spelunky 2 was great and I can't wait to play it much more and with friends in the coming weeks.

Edit: This is now my second favorite game and I have over 100 hours on the switch version. *6/22/2022

This game is just okay.  7 out of 10.  It has lots of problems but a few nice points.  High potential re-playability for those that don't mind all the issues it has.

This game is a two-d side scroller action game.  The purpose is not to kill things but to get to the end of the level.  Levels are randomly generated so every time it is different.  That is both a good thing for replayability but also just terrible when you get a random floor that is impossible to win.  If you don't mind games where your victory may not be in your hands then you might enjoy Spelunky 2. I personally never find it fun when my success in a video game is up to RNG over my actual skill and ability so overall I don't recommend this game.

Also, the music is outright TERRIBLE.  It's like 7 seconds of music on loop for the different levels. It isn't good enough to listen to or even qualify as a song in my books.  So the best choice is to mute music right away and play something in the background. 

Hit boxes are poor.  Your character's ability to whip attack is so pathetic in it's design it highlights to me that this was probably originally made as a video game student's final project that he then went on to expand into something bigger. But the rookie code that was built first was never improved because of laziness.  The whip attack is so small and poorly designed as to make it feel super useless.  In fact for no reason other than poor animation, it has a larger hit box behind your character then in front.  Consider that a whip, has bigger reach behind you then in front of you.  That's the quality you can expect from this game.

Spelunky's always been a fun and addicting game to play in your free time (at least for me), with it's extremely challenging and brutal game mechanics, it'll make you want to go at it again with slightly more confidence, or most likely, less confidence.  It'll take a lot of time to learn about what is Spelunky and how to "win", but that's the fun of it! :D

this game is great. it manages to be difficult while simultaneously suppressing our rage after seeing the dreaded game over screen. If "Murphy's Law" was encapsulated as a video game then look no further than Spelunky 2 (And its predecessor). It's a very tight 2D Roguelike platformer that is every bit demanding as it is humorous in it's execution. 

It's a game with a simple goal of spelunking downwards as far as you can go without dying. Each biome has its own respective set of enemies and platforming hazards that the player must use their reflexes and wit to deal with effectively.  Death will force the player back to the start with a clean slate with you losing previously made progress in terms of the distance covered and resources gathered for that run you failed. 

Progress overall is not really measured by "leveling up" a character or filling out a skill tree, but the experience the individual player gains that allows them to more effortlessly move through the game's challenges. Don't get frustrated with dying as it helps with expanding your knowledge on how to navigate the various threats the game throws at you as well as  understanding the general "language" of the game. Since this is a roguelike the levels are procedurally generated so there's an element of randomness in each playthrough, but each biome has their own specific set of threats/"rules" that you can always expect once you've learned about them.

A lot of the fun in Spelunky is trial and error using each run as an experiment to see what strategies work and what will get you killed. I think the humor lies in the fact you could hypothetically have a really good run going where you have plenty of resources, a large health pool, useful tools, and momentum then a small series of unfortunate events with NPCs or mob enemies could ruin it all. It's very cartoon-ish when things go wrong like an episode of Tom and Jerry but with a bit of added gore and blood. Though none of this is ever really "unfair" and usually the end of a run is due to a mix of impatience, recklessness, or ignorance when approaching certain hazards. Although there are sometimes you'll see a floor and wonder if the game hates you if you get some funky RNG with the level generation, but that's all in good fun.

The controls are really tight and feel really nice mechanically. They're simple but complex in the way you're able to interact with the environment around you. The art style is charming and adorable in comparison to how brutal the moment to moment gameplay can feel sometimes. The music fits the various biomes you'll trek without being distracting or grating on the ears. And the gameplay loop is very addicting once you get over the fact you'll die a lot and have to start over many times.

 Despite its difficulty I believe that Spelunky 2 can be enjoyed by anyone willing to be patient and give the game a fair shake. It's even more amusing with more people in multiplayer, but that also adds more elements of potential chaos that can occur if the gameplay between players is poorly coordinated.

Overall I highly recommend this game, there's lots of replay value in just the way the game is designed with tons of player choice from how you play to how you proceed as you progress from biome to biome. There's also a lot of collectibles, achievements, and hidden secrets for completionists that'll extend the gameplay length since they're typically challenging (meaning it will take time to become skilled enough to obtain them), but rewarding for committed players. Lastly you don't need to have played the first to enjoy this entry, in fact Spelunky 2 is more like an expansion in terms of having everything content wise from the first but adding upon it and refining the original formula to perfection.

It is a true rougelike in every sense, no real permanent unlocks (except shortcuts but they are not very useful except for practice maybe, and cosmetic skins), getting further and further simply because of pure skill and knowledge improvement is very satisfying. 

However after reaching 7-99 and getting all achievements i quickly tired of the game but that was after nearly 400 hours.

spelunky 2

[h1]Rating[/h1]
9/10 (S-tier)
To me this is one of the greatest roguelikes out there. It's addicting, challenging, full of personality and it has great changes compared to its predecessor.

[h1]Details[/h1]
Spelunky 2 is pretty much Spelunky HD but prettier, slightly harder, with different levels, some QoL improvements as well as a few nice new features. If you liked the first game, this one is a must-buy if you ask me.
If you never played a Spelunky game before then you should probably still play the HD version first because it's also a great game.

[h3]Pros[/h3]
[list]
[*]The music, art, sound effects and animations are great
[*]Very addicting because it's easy to pick up and regular runs aren't very long
[*]The basics of the game are very simple but there are many hidden tricks and things to learn
[*]There are some branching paths with different advantages and disadvantages, adding to replayability and making runs more interesting
[*]Many cool secrets
[*]Lots of risk vs. reward situations
[*]Online multiplayer is very fun (and works well in my experience - Besides slight framerate loss and lag sometimes)
[*]If you're looking for a really really challenging experience then there is a secret ending which requires godly skill and patience. The achievements also take considerable effort to get
[*]A decent amount of different items which will change how you approach many situations
[/list]

[h3]Cons[/h3]
[*]Default controls, at least on keyboard, are a bit weird in my opinion but can easily be changed to what you prefer so kind of a moot point (wanted to mention it anyway)
[*]Deaths can be frustrating
[*]While there are branching paths, you'll most likely prefer one over the other and end up always going the same way in the end
[*]Sometimes the game feels a little unfair but generally you're at fault when you take damage
[*]The secrets are kind of hard to find without someone telling you about them so you might miss out on some of the cool stuff. I suggest looking up the secrets online once you run out of ideas and patience
[*]The first world has some very annoying enemies and it punishes you a lot for being impatient. I think the majority of the game's community would agree that the first world could use some changes
[*]Some bugs but not many (if you don't count firebugs)
This is one of the most unforgiving (not unfair) rouge-likes I've ever played, and despite it being absurdly hard it's also really fun and I can't stop playing.

Precision is the key....

Precision in movement
Precision in decision making
Precision in time management

You waste time...you'll die
You make the wrong decision...you'll die
You act too greedy and it will catch up with you and...you'll die

Luckily for Spelunky 2 every part of the gameplay is enjoyable and meaningful. You can never feel sad about losing a good run as the next one might be even better.

It's also worth adding that the "scenarios" you find yourself dying within are so complex and surrounded in chance that each one feels...natural. The laws to which this games works are so well written that the unpredictable nature of death is replicated perfectly. It is truly magical in that after 50 hours you'll see it coming a mile off and still not be able to stop it. You will shout "I knew it...!" over and over again! It's simply beautiful programming...

A 2D platformer rogue-lite with unforgiving difficultly. Push through the learning curve and you will have a great time!  

Spelunky 2's difficulty lies in traversing randomly generated terrain filled with enemies and traps. It is difficult to get health back, so traversing levels without taking damage is critical. Developing this skill is rewarding but takes time. You will die. 

Luckily, Spelunky 2 is a fair game. You can anticipate any threat if you are careful enough. Items (especially bombs) can trivialize difficult encounters if used correctly. 

Multiplayer is an great addition and has crossplay.

[h1]One of the Greatest Video Games of All Time[/h1]

If there's a description I would give to describe the gameplay of Spelunky 2, it would be "perfectly balanced chaos". That phrase is a major contradiction, but so were my initial feelings on the game when it first released. I had a lot of fun in those first few hours. I also absolutely hated the game and how it would ruthlessly kick my ass at every turn without mercy. I liked the first game, but I was never a huge fan of it, and much like the first game, it felt needlessly difficult. 

But at a certain point, my opinion shifted completely.

It's hard to say when exactly my opinion shifted, but if I had to pinpoint it, it was after completing my first normal run. At a [i]very[/i] fundamental level, games can fall under four different categories:

[list]
	[*] Easy to learn, easy to master.
	[*] Easy to learn, hard to master.
	[*] Hard to learn, easy to master.
	[*] Hard to learn, hard to master.
[/list]

I used to think that out of these four options, "easy to learn, hard to master" was the best that a game should strive for, but after playing Spelunky 2 I realise that "hard to learn, hard to master" can be just as incredible. Whilst a game that is "easy to learn, hard to master" is great, only the speedrunning crowd will really care about that "hard to master" aspect of the game. Spelunky 2 forces you to master it as a mere means of surivival in its unforgiving world. Every tip and trick you find will be useful for all kinds of playthroughs - not just speedrunning. You begin to realise that you probably shouldn't risk life and limb to grab every little piece of gold. You figure out how to manipulate the shopkeepers to your advantage. You find the most optimal way to kill enemies and bosses.

And as you keep playing, hidden mechanics and details begin to reveal and unravel themselves to you in a natural, organic way, all through its gameplay. You begin to work out the best ways to use your bombs, ropes, and whip. You find out how to access secret areas you didn't even know existed. You figure out ways to skip entire sections of the game. 

Unlike roguelikes such as The Binding of Isaac or Enter the Gungeon, you don't unlock items, new areas, or anything that changes the gameplay in Spelunky 2. In Spelunky 2, everything has been there from the start, and the only thing that has progressed is your own skill. Where most roguelikes focus on synergies between the items you collect in a playthrough, Spelunky 2's focus is on the synergies between enemies, the environment, and the player. A trap roguelikes can fall into by focusing on item synergy is making the player horribly overpowered, or so underpowered that the run is over by no fault of the player. In Spelunky 2 this rarely happens due to the low item list: Each item is unique from each other, balanced with advantages and disadvantages, and often have one or two uses that are not immediately obvious to player. This adds so much depth that a game with 300+ items can feel shallow in comparison to Spelunky 2's well-crafted list of around 50 items. 

To go into details on the incredible secrets and the little details that Spelunky 2 hides would be a disservice to the game. If you think you have what it takes to tackle what is a [i]very[/i] difficult platformer I highly recommend Spelunky 2. As I discovered just how deep the rabbit hole goes in terms of its mechanics, my opinion changed from thinking of Spelunky 2 as a good game, to a great game, and then - finally - to perhaps my favourite game of all time. There aren't many games which come close to its genius, and its last challenge is so insane that I'll probably be playing this Kali-forsaken game for many years to come.

I'm not convinced Derek Yu and co. really knew what they were doing with this game. It's still Spelunky, just with more random crap thrown in. Things like the backlayers being worthless unless you're going for a specific area (Vlad's) are just so strange. More enemies, more items, a longer game - these are not necessarily good things in an extremely punishing roguelite where you can die in less than a second to something like a spark trap launching a UFO at mach 5. I think that there are too many bizarre interactions and edge cases; over 100 hours in and I'm still going "Wow that can happen?" I don't think this is a good thing. It just leaves me frustrated. Finally, things like the [spoiler]Cosmic Ocean[/spoiler] just scream to me that the devs think extreme length is an innately good thing. [spoiler]10 floors[/spoiler] would be a challenge most players would never complete. [spoiler]100[/spoiler] is sadism and disrespectful of the player's time.

The soundtrack is totally lame and does not compare even a little bit to the amazing soundtrack of the first game. All of the items are basically the same... I was really looking forward to new and interesting items. Save your money here Spelunky fans... this is just truly sad.

[b]Playing it on Nintendo Switch[/b] 
This game is challenging, but incredibly fun. 
The movement is really solid, there are plenty of good items that you can find, purchase or steal and it has different paths with semi-randomly generated levels.
If you are new, try out items and take it slow. Check out your surroundings and plan out an path. You will eventually become an expert speeding through previously difficult parts.
The best part of this game is that most of the time that you die is very much because of yourself.
------------------------

Performance has been good for me both on PC and Switch.
The music is also nice though it has less variety than Spelunky HD (which has an amazing soundtrack).
Online Adventure is mostly smooth but animations and enemy/player positions can start glitching out at poor connections. You could try and mitigate this by modifying your Online Input Latency setting. 3-5 should be good.
------------------------

[b]If you are on Nintendo Switch playing online games with Wi-FI like Splatoon 2 or whatever, please understand that the Switch wants to be closer to your router and that the connection will be MUCH more stable using an 5GHz Wi-Fi connection instead of 2.4GHz. The amount of players that lag or dissconnect in Splatoon 2 are too many.[/b]

A hilarious and outrages adventure from start to finish. Diving into spelunky 2 blind is exciting. Dying to nearly everything can become frustrating but its rewarding when you achieve the unachievable. I enjoyed playing the original and this one brings more to the table. This game is best played with others, especially those who are close to you.

I've played this game solo and its fun to unlocking new characters and learning how to platform through the world. You'll have less of difficult time with others, because human error can cause you to die faster than solo. On your own you can practice and play at your own pace. Solo gives you more features than playing online, like check points.

Online multiplayer is a blast but it can turn into a nightmare. Me and my buddies have killed each other multiple times by accident. Communication is needed if you're looking for secrets or items. But we laughed until tears came out of our eyes. Gathering items and gold is much faster together. Dying comes quickly and being able to revive each other is terrific! Its plain chaos with more people but worth the risk for a lifetime of laughter.

This game is sort of a skinner box. There are fun mechanics like teleportation, but whether or not you can get them is completely random. Otherwise, the second-to-second gameplay like moving around, attacking, and not taking damage just isn't fun. Most runs end to getting one-shot or stun-locked. Ideally you would learn something new or get better each run, but usually you don't, since you can do everything perfectly for 20 minutes and then make one mistake and die instantly.

It's spelunky  HD in better detail. Basically story is improved and more interesting questlines. But, at the same time, there's no actual way to make sure you have access to  maiden and  ghost pot without having to  rope/bomb in the first level. Level design  can be almost impossible in some cases, and boss design is....poor.

i've finally 100% this game. it's the second game (outside of some visual novels) i've sought every achievement. the only other game was chulip. yes, during this process i slowly went insane. scared my girlfriend every night i played. hit myself out of anger a few times. cried. popped blood vessels. but this is one of the greatest achievements i've ever had in my gamer career as a gaming gamer. the mood stabilizers and anti-depressants helped a bit, but i couldn't have gotten to this point without dedication. dedication i've had for very few projects in my life. i've loved other games (bayonetta, chulip, way of the samurai), but this has been a life-changing experience. even though i have no idea what to do with the rest of my life, i will never regret a second of these 300+ hours. i'm definitely going back in (i have to reach 7-99 after all), but this is the end of an era for me. i honestly can't recommend this to anyone. it's a masochistic experience that will make you lose sight of your family (unless you're 100x better at video games than i am [which i'm sure you are]). i've had several children taken away from me by CPS over the past year and a half. after you read this review, and message me about how i'm sexy and a godly gamer, you should look inside yourself and question if you are down for one of the most rewarding gaming experiences a person can go through.

I want to recommend this game, but I can't.  Just play Spelunky 1 instead.

The reason is simple: the first world is completely, ridiculously overtuned.  It's harder than everything else that comes after it.  It took me dozens of tries to get through it the first time, and I immediately breezed through the second world and made it well into the third before dying.  It took me twenty more tries to get past the first world again and repeat my previous experience.  If the game gradually built up its difficulty, that'd be one thing, but instead it has a huge wall you have to beat your head against to overcome before you can see anything else every time you play the game.

I waited a while to write this review because I was hoping it'd get adjusted, but it hasn't.  Sure, this game looks great, the controls are tight, and there's a lot of content... but it's going to take you an hour of dying every time you want to see anything other than the Dwellings.

This game is really difficult, and early on, there will be alot of things that will kill you for no reason. But you gotta keep going! Once you get past the first area, the game REALLY starts. You will find more traps and enemies, and the stakes are high as ever! You must be super careful. Can I get that diamond without triggering that mace trap? Is getting that idol worth it? Should I steal these bombs or buy them? Spelunky is all about risk and reward. Almost every death is your fault (except during the last few levels) and there is always something to learn from every death, and you will always feel the negative consequences of a bad decision and the rewards of a good decision. Overall, just play the game. $20 is a small price to pay for the perfection that is this masterpiece, don't give up, you will beat it eventually through trial and error. There are many secrets to discover, you might put 2 and 2 together and find a secret in a chest or you may accidentally uncover a secret NPC with a misplaced bomb. The possibilities are endless! Literally, level generation is random, encouraging you to learn the mechanics instead of the levels.

my all time favorite game, hands down. this is a proper game through and through. spelunky 2 teached me profound wisdoms about how to design games and even how to live life. it's a game that doesn't owe you a win, you must earn it by speaking its language to a fluent degree. some days your runs may look dire, but try tomorrow and plenty of big chances will open up. and you might die in one sobering hit in the very next floor. or die in a very spectacular way. or you will score a win. you might even wanna gamble to achieve one of the harder endings, but it will just make the game exponentially harder for you. the amount of decisions per second and the level of concentration you need make this game exhaustingly difficult, that's why many people may not like it. but I've seen people that are better than me just for the fact because they do better choices, even if they are platformer noobs. endure the first few deaths and the feeling of the game 'owing you' a win, or lending you a hand. something beautiful will unfold before your eyes if you persist.

Spelunky 2 is a rogue-like platformer where you get to the bottom of each level and gather gold and resources such as bombs and ropes. You can also use the gold to buy resources such as spring boots which allow you to jump 50% higher. There are plenty of secrets like the gist shop which you can only enter when you are cursed. The objective is to kill Tiamat to win. I recommend playing it because it has a lot of replay value.

Great game with polished game design and lots of cool mechanics and ways to work around puzzles and stuff, although sometimes the game can be extremely unfair and totally based on RNG its uncommon for that to happen, after alot of updates the devs tried their hardest to fix unfair deaths and accidental softlocks, also its procedural generation is more than amazing, what i like about its generation is that some areas of the stage are authored meaning the shop for example will always have certain types of shapes and wont get affected by the generation system same thing with udjat chest ladders, also its has really nice balance of difficulty, i like that the game doesnt focus on its core gameplay it also makes the player enjoy other funny things like cave men talking to each other and arguing with each other really cute stuff, creating your own community in the base camp, and much more other stuff, really big jump from spelunky 1, ofc the game isn't perfect no game is or will be but its design and core mechanics and other stuff go with each other in harmony, thanks derek for creating one of the best games ive ever bought in myentire life.

This game, there's difficult and then there's go screw yourself difficult.
Well, if the game developers want to tell me to go screw myself with the sheer amount of difficulty they stacked into this game, they can go do the same. 
Health doesn't matter, most things one hit kill you or stun you to death or combine with the rest of the cluttered levels to chain reaction kill you and then it's all the way back to either the start or to the shortcut with a severe money and equipment deficit. 
Oh but to get health you have to waste bombs on the poor turkeys you got killed accidentally or getting your pet to the exit without getting it killed accidentally.
So here we have a game where you're always one mistake away from dying, everything else chips away at your health making you have to stock up and trying to get the health can lead to you taking even more risks and more damage and then stocking up doesn't matter in the long run because you're always one mistake away from dying as I mentioned before.
I have hours and hours on rogue-likes that are actually rewarding to play, with a more fair sense of balance but actually challenge you instead of just pretending to do so while giggling and killing you over and over like this game seems to like to do. Feel free to use the comment section of this review to ask for recommendations.

Game is very fun, but VERY difficult. Some people enjoy a difficult game similar to how some people enjoy spicy food. If you're are a masochistic gamer looking for a challenge then this game is for you. But maybe start with the prequel first (Spelunky HD) before you try this game. It's cheaper and more well balanced. And if you like then you will like Spelunky 2.

As for Spelunky 2, the difficulty sometimes comes from the game unfair's randomness. There are several ways your good run can be ruined through no fault of your own. Additionally, the starting area of this game may be too difficult for new players. All these combined can demotivate you and making you wanting to quit the game right from the first few levels. Remember, it's a roguelike, dying is a part of the gameplay. Eventually you will get there, and honestly it's very fun once you get the hang of it.

Spelunky HD is, in my opinion, a nearly perfect video game. Spelunky 2 doesn't quite rise to that level, but its pretty dang close, and does a remarkable job holding its own while trying to follow up perfection (or near-perfection). I think there are two main reasons that it doesn't quite live up to its predecessor for me: One, in HD, you'd often meet your demise in crazy, unanticipated ways, but it never felt unfair; in 2, it does, very occasionally, feel unfair (and then I'll be awed by the platforming skills and quick reactions of streamers or youtubers, so "unfair" could admittedly be subjective). Two, while the sequel adds a lot of depth in some areas with new zones, new items and enemies, branching paths, etc, some of that depth sometimes feels somewhat shallow, if that makes sense. A lot of the new gear will hardly ever see use, especially for veterans of HD like me, stuck in their ways (the significant nerf to the jetpack goes some way toward making some of those items interesting enough to consider, though many of them share the jetpack's new flaws, so it really only ends up bringing the capes up to par). The back layers are an interesting addition, especially in the implementation of the black market and wet fur zones, but often just feel kind of tacked on and inconsequential. New mechanics like curse and poison are just one way the difficulty is ramped up, but new ways to gain health like royal jelly from Kali altars and turkeys make things significantly easier in others. All of this goes to make for some unevenness in terms of both difficulty and pacing. But I don't want to overstate it, and i can't overstate this: Spelunky 2 is still a really, REALLY good game, worth the hundreds of hours I have and will spend within its shifting walls, and more than worth every penny spent on it, at full or sale price.

Honestly, being a fan of the original Spelunky (I even played the original before HD was a thing), I thought the game should have more new stuff. The only stage that feels new is the Tide Pool. Volcana is the new Hell. Sunken City is the new Worm. Excalibur is the new Crysknife. I can go on. While HD felt like a great expansion of the Classic world, this one feels like it's just trying to recicle the formula one more time.

There are some great additions though. The backpacks and mounts are nice. But it's just not enough to justify the existence of this game.

This game is one of the best games I have ever played, not only did they take the charm of the first game and remaster the art style they also made this game in a way that old fans would be able to have the same experience as new players and feel like as if they were playing Spelunky for the first time again, which is a magical experience. And new players can feel the joy of trying to traverse the levels while figuring out how to not die so easily, new players will also feel the excitement of trying to uncover the mystery of the caves and all it has to offer, and no run will feel the same as the levels are half auto generated and half authored which is a genius way of making it so you never get tired of the game because of how replayable it is. If you do ever get tired of an area you simply can go a different route because this game has branching paths which diversifies the experience in such a simple yet brilliant way. The characters are so charming and are so much fun to unlock because they feel like prizes for getting to certain areas. The game gets even better because you can explore this magical yet mysterious game with friends and if you're by yourself you can play with randoms, this game even features crossplay. and if none of that convinces you then there is one more thing i have to say about this game to try and convince you to buy it, you can pet the dog. 10/10

When I originally left this review, I found seeded runs helped me progress so I wanted to re-evaluate how I felt about Spelunky 2. But this game still feels closer to a neutral recommendation for me. Playing with friends is a lot of fun and alleviates most of my gripes. Playing solo is still mostly only fun if you have speedrunner levels of dedication. Be prepared to reset your runs. Sometimes early and often to get a good start. If speedrunning is not your thing and you don't have friends to play this game with, recommendations are with those caveats in mind. Maybe if you're willing to mod the game for variety, it could be worth as the platforming and level progression are very good overall (assuming you can progress). Please do not mod your Spelunky 2 install directly to avoid cheats in direct relation to Steam and all that. There's gonna be some spoilers here, but I'll try to keep it vague.

At it's base, Seplunky 2 is a solid 2D platformer. It comes with various upgrades and tools to navigate through the caves, along with various enemies to work around. The movement feels a bit too fast and spastic at times, with hitboxes that can be unforgiving or feel inconsistent. But overall, it can be very smooth. It combines the unforgiving nature of Dead Cells, the utter bullcrap of Dark Souls, along with the obscure pathfinding of a Hollow Knight, all into one (I said this in my original review but still feel it best summarizes the experience). On paper it sounds great. But in execution, it's a bit too brutal at times.

Getting to new locations can be quite rewarding, especially with the struggle just about every level can pose. So many runs can end at any moment to a split second decision, so you want to be on guard at all times. Money can be useful for upgrades, but also a distraction which can put you in situations that whittle away your health or combo you to death.

I've restarted 1000-ish times and beat the first-ish boss, got all the shortcuts, unlocked seeded runs, looked up half the game I'm missing, checked out speedrunner strats, checked out the devs reacting to speedrunner strats, tried to figure out if there's anything new in any area I've been already, and I still don't know how this game was meant to be played. Shortcuts seem best only for bragging rights and a little practice. There are achievements which require you to do them in what I would consider the easier way. (Beat the game without shortcuts? Which shortcut is even good?) I tend to not always piece things together the first way one should, so there's probably a few things I'm being dense about.

The first couple of worlds are where I normally worry about money, as I can't find shops anywhere later on. It starts to give this strange sensation that getting money normally just leads to lost health, so robbing a shopkeeper just ends up helping me navigate the worlds and fend off enemies. Later levels start to follow a trend of more hazards and enemies in tighter spaces. While a nice change of pace after running through early worlds, it gets to be a bit absurd when the level is too busy killing itself and all you need to do is stay out of the crossfire (takes care of the shopkeepers for me). Which a lot of the game in general will kill itself and then blame you for it. Sometimes you can be the culprit, but I've delivered turkeys for Turkey Man (definitely his name) and he dropped a key for me on his turkeys and then killed me for it. The game seems very unable to actually kill the player efficiently, so it makes up for it by sharting damage and aggro for no reason the longer it goes. And for how much I'm expecting things like making the shopkeepers mad or whatever else to kill me, often times I'm getting one shot by terrain. I've even been killed by a flying arrowhead that did zero damage but dropped me onto a conveyor belt which delivered me onto spikes. I wish I could say this doesn't happen often, but that's pretty much how most runs go. Something benign turns into a stun which delivers death. I'm still going back to 1-1 all the same.

For the other half of the game, you still need to go through a couple sequences in the first two worlds for 2 items. Both required for just about any path other than the first-ish boss (give or take advanced tech and/or cheese). At first, it seems fine, but it gets so incredibly tedious to constantly redo these sequences, hoping to find your change of pace in world 3, only to be done in by instant-death mechanics. I've never been a fan of instant-death mechanics. At best, they're annoying once in a while, and at worst, they start to feel like a lazy way to keep the game going. Half the things on screen are likely to kill you at any moment. Along with combo chains that can easily snowball. It is possible to commit no mistakes and still start world 5 with an explosion careen from offscreen the first second the level loads and end your run. That is not weakness. That is Splunkying.

This game is not dynamic enough for it to focus on the singleplayer aspect this much. Multiplayer focus would have been nicer, as it helps alleviate just about all the issues stated above (dividing tasks for the two sequences, not having to restart on one minor error made 5 worlds in, etc...). But couch co-op doesn't have split screen and online doesn't seem to have access to shortcuts, unlocking characters, and arena bots (I believe, but I also still don't know what unlocked my seeded runs). Instead, a lot of what the game offers is something very clip worthy while livestreaming. It is a lot of fun. I livestreamed with friends for my birthday. But 1000 restarts solo is just too much for what this game actually is. Clip worthy, speedrunner ready, solid platforming, and great cooperative shenanigans. And that's the high note I'll leave it on.

Where do I begin? Derek Yu and Mossmouth have done it again. Spelunky HD is still one of my favorite games of all time, and Spelunky 2 is now right there next to it complementing it in every way. Standing on the shoulders of a giant, Spelunky 2 is a tribute to its roots as it creates a masterpiece giant twice as tall. Expanding on virtually every game element from the first for increased replayability (when it was already infinitely replayable) and adding a "back layer", diverging world paths, and even more endings, Spelunky 2 continues to forge its own path. It's the quintessential roguelike platformer playground where every player choice matters every second for unfathomably infinite permutations. Over 100 hours in, and I just want more. Spelunky 2 is extremely challenging and still feels extremely rewarding when you pull off what seemed impossible. A crucial bonus, again, is how fun it is both to play solo and with co-op play, with a very different dynamic for each. Whether you bring your friends, or go solo, I simply cannot recommend Spelunky 2 highly enough. Warning: it's OK to die; just one more run...

Spelunky 2:
This game is about the rouguelike experience. Now what do I mean by that, well I believe this game has four main sections that I believe are worth discussing, Movement, Items, Level Design, and Difficulty.

To start I will be discussing Movement. In terms of movement options, you have a walk, run, jump, clamber, and that's it. The movement is very simple, although this incentives the use of items, so that you will have more movement options or other various power tools at your disposal.

Items: The items in Spelunky 2 have many utilities, and purposes, to start I will go over the basic items you start with bombs, and ropes. Bombs and Ropes are both items that are consumed over a gameplay session each providing different utilities, the bombs blow stuff up, whilst ropes let you climb up to higher locations. The next items are equipment, these items are applied to the player character similar to a backpack and each can provide different helpful tools to a player, for example a jetpack to fly, a cape to glide, or a power pack to power up your attacks. Speaking of attacks, the final item type is the weapons and items that you are able to pick up, these items consist of guns, weapons like boomerangs, and even magical weapons that have special properties.

The level design is a short and simple discussion. The game is a roguelike and as such will have a nearly random generation for every level in the game even having special locations that will appear in certain locations if you know what to look out for, but new to the series is a choice between different locations, for example the jungle, or the volcano areas.

Finally there is the difficulty, what I feel is the greatest part of this game. To be absolutely honest, this game loves to not through it's punches, and is absolutely brutal. The tutorial shows you the tools at your disposal, but the rest of the game you have to figure out how to do tasks, you have to learn so much about this game, and you are more than likely to die on your first run-through of the game, but if you stick with it, you will get good, and you will learn to overcome so many obstacles.

To finish out this review, I hope you will join me on this adventure, by buying the game, as I believe this to be an excellent game, and the extra content that I chose to leave out as I believe it is a discovery when you learn how to do a lot of it, will be worth the purchase.

Here are a few tips, so you dont put a bad review because you suck: (looking at you Jim, you c*nt)

1 - Don't try to speedrun every level, as every level/area has a purpose (secret ending?)

2 - There is always a clear path to the exit, don't go using bombs or ropes to go somewhere, unless you are sure to have some extra resources (or worth it, like a jetpack or getting more resources than spent, trading 1 bomb for 3 bombs)

3 - Be careful of what you carry (MY GOD STOP USING THE METAL SHIELD ON MULTIPLAYER JIM!)

4 - Always look down and above you when going somewhere (if you go far enough, you will know that this will save your life more times than you can count)

5 - The whip hits behind you at a diagonal angle (45 degrees), perfect for bats and spiders!

6 - DEREK REMOVE MOLES JESUS CHRIST THEY ARE SO ANNOYING

7 - Play the game, without spoilers, and when you beat it or are really strugling, research secrets or stuff you don't know

8 - PLEASE, have a good idea of the game before you go to multiplayer, or you will have no idea of what is happening and you wont be able to play at all

9 - Remember: Kali altars exist, use them!

10 - Have fun dying! Every death is worth ragequitting and entering the game 3 seconds later!

Spelunky 2 is one of the best and the hardest roguelike platformers out there. The sequel was executed pretty much almost perfectly and is packed with even more content and playability than its predecessor. It does have a couple weaker points, like the soundtrack (Spelunky HD offered a variation between level music and it was generally more lively), weird level generation (too many arrow traps or moles, weird "puzzle" patterns) and weird difficulty scaling (The Dwelling (first stage) is harder than the later stages).

I'd say my favourite aspect of this sequel is not all the new content, but rather the fact that the developers stayed incredibly truthful to the previous part, making the spirit of Spelunky ever-present while also implementing several "serious" changes (I hate the new climbing gloves, though). All the tiny nudges, easter eggs and lore elements make the world quite lively.

I've spent about 600 hours in Spelunky HD and I'm hoping to spend even more in the sequel, keep it up Derek.

I got this game last October and after playing around 20 hours I got bored and put it down for over a year. Just recently picked it up again out of boredom, and after 3 weeks and 40 hours I finally beat Tiamat.  This game is a treasure if you put in the correct work and effort into it. The joy you will feel when getting deeper than you ever had is great, but that is not to say that you won't want to rip your hair out. I don't think I've ever felt such polar emotions than in this game. 99% of the time I want to throw my computer out the window and that 1% of unadulterated joy is what makes it all worth it. This game is a game that you must be willing to figure out all of its ins and outs to get your true enjoyment. Spelunky will punish you in the most brutal and unforgiving ways, but it just makes beating  it that much more pleasing. There are loads of secrets to discover (unless you're like me and just looked them all up on Youtube) and there is way more content in this game than any regular person has the capacity to get through. In all, this is not a game for everyone, but those who are up for a souls-like cartoony dungeon crawler, then go right ahead. EDIT: Finally beat Hundun after what seems like a year. . I now feel I am truly done with the gam , but I cant recommend the game more to those who are up for a challenge

So, I've thought about this a while, the review and all, and here's my heavily summarised sentence; 
I love this game, but I wouldn't recommend it unless you're either a content creator, or have friends to play with; though, The sole exception to this is if you've completed Spelunky 1 and want more. 
*Spoiler warning Below!* 
To Summarise: 

The Good
-  There's a lot to do in this game, it's got a really good amount of secrets and discovery; it captures the theme of adventure incredibly well. 
- The animations are very smooth and the art is great, a clear and concise visual upgrade from the previous title and a game that's almost always nice on the eyes
- The gameplay is still really enjoyable most of the time, with good controls and satisfying movement
- The Multiplayer is simply incredible, and easily the best part of the game; It really is better with friends, The deaths become funny and the run isn't immediately over when one person makes a mistake. not to mention, outside of other players' movement, lag is nonexistant. It's really incredible how Mossmouth did it.

The Bad 
- Dwellings is Incredibly, violently repetitive and if you do not have the drive or skill to constantly get past it, You won't enjoy the game. 
- In spelunky 1, most deaths were fair, and the few Rube's Machines to send you to 1-1 were at least, rare enough to be funny, but in spelunky 2 I often find myself not even reacting when one kills me.
- Neo Babylon has the most, cheap and out of control deaths of any area in spelunky history with it's combination of UFOs, Reflecting shields and crushing Elevators. It's not fun; no sane person is arguing that a UFO going mach 9 to teleport you to 1-1 is Well designed and fair 
- While Discovering the secrets is great, Actually doing them is a different story. Spelunky 2 feels as if the Udjat eye spawns in resource-demanding locations so much more than 1, and Olmec's 3 phases still drag on way too long; for something essential to progression 
- I lose brain cells everytime a Shopkeeper outpost spawns with a ghost jar in it. Seriously; Why is that even possible, they always shoot it and it summons the ghost and forces you to speedrun an area with shopkeepers in it 
- I still don't understand why shops don't have a door, or some form of, Entry protection; Firemen, Lizards and Dart Traps can often spawn in front of shops, and if that shop has a bomb bag in it then it simply ceases to exist when the shopkeeper channels their Inner Mr. Sir, and uses a double barrel shotgun to take out a lizard. Seriously, the only reason I can assume this exists is because it generates those "Family Guy Funny Moments" compilations where a lizard rolls into a shop and proceeds to blow up the entire shop because of a powerpack and oneshot the player inside of it. It's funny the first 5 or 6 times but, it gets old fast
- The Music, now, don't get me wrong, the Music is Incredible, an OST worth buying, however; each area has one track, unlike 1 where each level has 3. this contributes to the problem I mentioned above, where the dwellings are repetitive, as the music is always, Always identical. 

Overall, I can't recommend the game unless you have friends or an audience. A lot of the downsides are negated by that; The violently repetitive nature of it, the unfair deaths that stop being funny after a while, etc etc. It's a good game, but, Get spelunky 1 instead, and *then*, only then, if you really desire more, get spelunky 2.

This is a game of survival. The goal is to get to the end. Nothing more, nothing less. This game may have a nice a cheery look on the outside, but once you jump into the fray, you have REALLY jumped into the fray. This game is just straight up BS because of it's incredibly unforgiving nature and lack of invincibility. Realistically, if you get hit once or twice, you are DEAD. Restart from the caverns with your four health, four bombs, four ropes and a DREAM. And that is what makes Spelunky, well, Spelunky! Regardless of the deaths, regardless of the restarts, regardless of the friend betrayals, this game is fun as HELL. This really is rouge-like taken to the next level. The fact that this game has random seeds makes the routing and resource management unique and honestly exciting! The different worlds, items, new and revamped enemies, mechanics, and endings just show how much love was put into this game. Mossmouth and BlitWorks took what was good about the first game and just expanded to a degree that was COMPLETELY unnecessary but absolutely appreciated (at least by us true fans). And co-op turns the game from brutal to DEAD UP HILARIOUS. Content with bad friends for this game is amazing just because you die in so many different ways so instantly, which comes full circle. The fact that it's BS hard makes the game what it is. Yes, I have pounded my fist against my table in frustration. That doesn't make the game bad. The fact that it is the way it is makes it all the more satisfying when you get that extra inch further. It might be painful, but it is incredible. 11/10 game, would recommend to EVERYONE (who can handle constant death and cults and blood lol)

Was expecting a fun, casual co-op platform frolic.
Got a frustrating, random-death simulator and co-op was further frustrating due to friendly fire issues.
Is it an 'internet joke' that this game is so popular?

Although the game has nice visuals and cool music, It'd be difficult to recommend it to any new players. First off, as a rouge-like, it is odd that although the levels are randomly generated, they all play out the exact same. That isn't a huge issue, but its annoying in already tedious areas like the dwelling. Secondly, bad game design decisions make the game unplayable. The game is not difficult, it is easy when played slowly and when the player is focused. But it is extremely tedious to deal with the same obstacles every run. Additionally, there are many deaths in the game which are caused by things off screen, and health does not matter often times as a single hit will stun-lock you and you will die regardless. The game starts out with the dwelling which is already the most tedious area in the game. It is filled with clusters of traps and enemies and getting hit by a single lizard will cause death (due to perma-stun). It is a very easy area because every enemy is easily avoided but the halls are littered with traps and in order to keep your lives, you would have to trek through the area slowly. And its the same thing every time in a game where you die every couple minutes. Restarting in the dwelling each time is practically unbearable. Luckily, there is a check point system implemented. In order to unlock a checkpoint, the player will have to deliver 3 different items to the end of a biome. However, you start out with no items, and shop keepers are scarce after olmec. I personally hit a brick wall each biome very quickly where I was not improving in the slightest and I just waited for a fluke to make it past or I could play slowly and drop bombs to skip the level but there is zero fun in that. Even after completing the game, I only make it past the dwelling by fluke or by playing it out very slowly, which is extremely boring, especially in a rougue-like. Its only replayabilty comes with its extreme ease to die at any area in the game. After completion, there is no reason to play on which isn't a good look for a roguelike. The world gen is abysmal often time, not only with the levels playing out the same, but especially in tidal pool, the door can sometimes be completely blocked off. There will be a 1 block gap in which an explosive crab resides, which if hit with a whip is an instant death. This is just one example of a common issue plaguing the game at every turn. The enemy ai is also very awkward in certain areas and missing a jump on an enemies head by a single pixel results in lives lost or death and the hitboxes are pretty small. Without the bad game decisions, this game would be pretty great due to side quests and multiple routes, but it suffers from bad choices.

After 100+ hours, here's my official review of Spelunky 2:
Despite never actually beating the game or never even reaching Tiamat after 100+ hours of frustrating and rage-inducing deaths, there is something so charming and perfect about this game that keeps me coming back and I think it will not be long before I have 200 and then 300 hours in Spelunky 2. In my opinion this game is one of the best available on Steam, even above popular titles like Call of Duty and Borderlands, but I suppose that's just my personal taste. Every time I play I end up rage quitting, but then I'll play another game and then come right back or I'll just find myself coming back the next day. I really can't imagine myself stopping Spelunky 2 entirely, even if I finally beat the darn thing, unless I stop playing video games as a whole or something. Regardless, the controller feels so perfect and smooth playing and every death truly feels like my own foolish fault, rather than some glitch or technical error; everything is perfect down to a T. I wish I could give more praise and I might post another review after many many more hours but this is an overwhelmingly positive game in my opinion and experience. Try it out, you'll hate it and yourself so much better I promise :')

He also has a rare weapon "quicksave/scrap, but its not good as him by any means, as he has a very limited inventory so that weapon can only be used once per level.

Pro, con, unknown: unknown since the last title.

Mela Tsuukamaki

If I could explain him to you like he does to a japanese movie-scene he would look very cool. She's unique to every level and all her abilities suit her gameplay better than every other character, she has a melee weapon like every other character but unlike the others it cannot be replaced on death, she's a pioneer with most of the unique and optional items and she takes no damage. This is the female "everything" of Spelunky, with the breasts of caves and the non-lethal sword of sci-fi superheroines.

Pro, con, unknown: dangerous.

The Hardest Challenge to Finish In Spelunky is the one where you have a ten way fight with your own death, multiple auto-attacks of your enemies, a dead-end that sends you to a very cramped area where you have to fight your way out and fight 3 bosses with highly dangerous attacks with a sword the size of a doorknob.

When you fail, you automatically come back with half your health. When you "die" your death will be permanent.

And if you aren't willing to die, you will also have a timer that counts down your mission in Spelunky. When you see the timer you have to spend the time to kill every enemy on the way until you get the time to move your hovercraft or escape Spelunky. Because of the way the time mechanic works, there's a chance that you will die while coming back with the time to start again, because you can't move your hovercraft or escape Spelunky during the timer.

Pro, con, unknown: there's no indication on the UI of the time limit.

I've been a huge fan of the rogue-like genre for many years now, starting all the way back with the Binding of Isaac. From there, the genre has exploded into many different variations of randomly generated levels and perma-death level difficulty; where the stakes are high and the rewards of succeeding feel that much sweeter. Spelunky was a title that, in certain variations, has existed even as far back as Isaac and it was a game i had always heard about, but never really knew if I would enjoy it.

With Spelunky 2, I decided the time was right to take the plunge; this quirky little platformer could be a bit of fun. Little did I know, this game would bring me immense frustration, laughter, elation, anger, excitement, and feelings of discovery. This game is unforgiving and doesn't hold your hand; it drops you in and leaves you to find your own way out. Maybe that's not for everyone, but at this point in my life, this game has become my favourite in all of the rogue-like genre.

Being able to overcome a level or boss brought me incredible satisfaction; being able to discover secrets and secrets within secrets probed me to dig deeper; getting to a point in the game when you think it's all over only to discover that there's much more. These are the things I've experienced from this game and being able to play with friends and seeing their exact same emotions as mine is something that makes me want to share this with everyone.

With most rogue-likes, there is usually a large slew of items you can pick-up that gives you a unique "build" for each run you do of the game. The lack of items in Spelunky means that most of the variation exists in the way the levels are generated; and sometimes, that variation is cursed. I've found that having a small pool of items makes almost all them useful in some way, so no matter the seed that is generated, you know that when you pick up an item, it will prove to be helpful to you in some way.

In regards to the level design, you're fighting against the RNG; sometimes it works in your favour, sometimes you're left to figure out the best escape route possible. Sometimes, the items you need are generated and easy to pick-up or purchase from the shop. Sometimes, the only clean way out is to go down a route and avoid traps and enemies. The more you play this game, the more you are able to navigate the variations in levels better than you ever thought you could.

In almost 100 hours played on Steam as of writing this, and not to mention the time i've spent on the Switch and PS4 as well, this game is an experience for those looking for a meaningful one. If you are patient and determined, I feel like this game can reward you for the time you put in and will keep you coming back to see if you can beat it again and again. I would recommend this game to everyone and hope you, too, can beat this game, even if it's just to say "I did it".

This is a really well designed game. The learning curve is high, but once you become competent at not dying in stupid ways, so much freedom is opened up to the player. There are a dozen steps you need to follow to get the true ending for the game, but if you're good (and I mean insanely good) you can use your extreme skills to skip as many, if not all the steps, that you want. This creativity is part of the spirit of the game and makes you feel like you have an endless amount of freedom and places to improve your runs. 

p.s
There are a lot of people in the reviews talking about how the game is too hard and basically unplayable. No offense to them, but they are pretty much just mad cuz mad.

Incredible fun. Challenging, and often times unfair, but never leaves you feeling cheated. The game inspires an endless curiosity, as you wonder what lies beyond the next stage. Any criticisms? Moles suck and the cosmic ocean is a little boring. Otherwise? One of the few games I'd call essentially perfect.

Spelunky 2 is a rougelike, hard platformer that will kill you, over and over again relentlessly, but thats the beauty of the game itself.
"What does this trap do?"
"Whats the best way to steal from the shopkeeper?"
"Can i abuse this mechanic...?"
The game wants you to experiment with pretty much everything, and upon doing so you either just straight up die and get rewarded with knowledge of the game, or end up with rewards to get to get further in your run (or well, you take damage)

The gameplay never gets old. The game offers 16 biomes, in which a number of them require you to do specific objectives, in which again encourages expermentation. When doing a run, there are branching paths (as seen in the trailer) so every run feels fresh and infinitely replayable. Oh, and multiplayer is really great for this game lmao, its of those type of games that end up in a chaotic playthrough with your friends sabotaging one another or just dying hilariously. And if youre lonely with no one to play spelunky with, theres a discord server for this game and you can simply find people there to play with you

Lastly, this game has mods! And holy shit, i love the mods in this game (ill put a link of a yt tutorial video i used on how to do so at the bottom. Youll need it.)

So in conclusion, really, really.good game with infinite replayablity and about the price... in my opinion, buy it on sale, i bought mine during the chirstmas sales though, not sure when its gonna have another.

https://youtu.be/DZd3WPp_T84
