Since the thumbs up or down stands for whether i would recommend the game or not, albeit having 80 hours in the game as of now i honestly cannot recommend buying or playing it so i have to give a thumbs down. 

The game has a whole ton of interesting, diverse and well designed content but the problem is that all that content comes after the first 10 or so minutes of each run (even 30 minutes is not absurd) Because you will be forced to play the first stage which consists of 4 levels every single run to get to the fun point. For your first dozens of hours you will be stuck in the first stages until you get past the first boss, and these first stages happen to be the most boring and tedious ones for some inexplicable reason. With tons of bullet sponge enemies and an absolute time waste of a mini-boss. It is an extremely easy but tedious stage that is filled with traps, enemies with almost the most hp in the entire game and some quest like things that are the same every single run. If you play slow it's impossible to lose but never fun. 

In less than probably 5 hours you will have seen almost every item in the game and will have to do the exact same "quests" every single run for the first 30 minutes. If you happen to get past that after hours of game-play you will find yourself in a new stage and will die to some kind of trap due to lack of familiarity for sure. Then you will have to spend all that time to get past the first stage again, which will be extremely discouraging. You will be tempted to play fast and careless which will cause you to die more so you'll have to spend even more time in these stages. In the end no matter how good you get at least 80 percent of your overall playtime will probably be spent on the first stages doing the exact same things. 

The game is filled with good content but for some reason they decided to put all that after the worst, the most boring, the most time consuming and repetitive levels of the game.

Another thing to note is that due to the repetitiveness of the game there are no "fun" seeds, there are only good or bad seeds, an altar spawning in a run is a hundred percent good and a key spawning behind some wall is a hundred percent bad, there is a little number of items with all having only positives and no negatives, having more items is always good and least items bad, item positions good or bad. The game feels more like a regular platformer with randomly generated levels than the roguelike me and probably some others are used to where every run is a different experience with some pros, some cons and an interesting combination of items leading to different strategies each run. The level generation in this game is either good or bad with a strict line.

TLDR besides being repetitive  It is more of a tedious game than a hard one, if your life depended on it you would win it first try but if you are like me you will get to see some new and cool stuff one time, die to some new mechanic due to not being familiar then gets ruck in a loop of playing less and less careful and spending hours in the first stage because it is the most tedious and time consuming one. But if you are some kind of platforming god the game is for you because it is no doubt filled with content.

I triple dipped this game on PS4, Switch, and now Steam. I don't like platformers much but this game has very crisp controls and deep mechanics. It's not like Hollow Knight but I would put it on the same tier of platformers with an exceptional game feel.

The world design of Spelunky 2 is so neat, drawing from various cultures. The game also has a souls-like system for side quests. Quests are cryptic, the quest NPCs will just show up in unexpected spots as you dive deeper into the caves, and all NPCs can be killed. The implied connections between the various characters are delightful as well.

The game is hard as dirt, truly unrelenting, but generally fair (except for the Low Scorer achievement). There is no meta progression to make the game easier like you'd find in other roguelites. And as a general rule the more powerful or useful an item is the more dangerous it can be when used by inexperienced players. The teleporter lets you bypass large sections of levels but also allows you to teleport yourself into a wall, resulting in instant death. The jetpack lets you fly over dangerous obstacles and avoid using ropes to ascend but it also has a tendency to explode when exposed to fire or if punctured. Your only hope of surviving the brutal cycle of death and rebirth in the caves are your wits and experience accumulated over hundreds of failures.

Good luck, and take care of your mental. You'll need both for the journey ahead.

Looking at it from an objective standpoint, this is a decent game. Tons of interactions and unique runs, and possessing a good amount of polish. Unfortunately this game's sheer difficulty kills my ability to have fun with it. 

Permadeath roguelikes can be enjoyable if you feel you are making progress each time - usually this comes in the form of permanent unlocks or stat bonuses so subsequent runs are easier until you eventually beat the game. Spelunky doesn't have this, and it is possible to just get permanently stuck because you lack the skill needed to play perfectly enough to get past every obstacle. 

This game leans too far into difficulty for the sake of difficulty.

Spelunky 2 is an experience inferior in every way to its predecessor. Just play Spelunky 1; unless you are the sort of challenge-addict who does eggplant runs for fun, Spelunky 2 adds nothing of value for you.

Spelunky 1 was charming for the minimalism of its design and the extremism of its gameplay. The experience of being struck from an arrow-trap at the far edge of the screen and sent flying into a row of run-ending spikes was novel at the time; the consequences of errors were severe and would heavily punish careless play, but nearly any foreseen and understood threat could be avoided with only moderate platforming ability. The combination of those two traits was important: if you got stunned and sent flying, the wacky exaggerated physics meant that the consequences could range from slightly-damaging to fatal, but threats were sufficiently noticeable and telegraphed that this result was generally due to a significant and understandable misplay on the player's part, or the punishment for a 'greedy' maneuver. This also meant that the game could get away with various little clumsinesses; because the game's challenges were only moderately mechanically demanding, it didn't matter so much that some parts of the execution were awkward.  

Spelunky 2 treats the game of Spelunky as though it needs no basic improvements or updates, and only needs increased difficulty. Much content is shamelessly unchanged; for someone expecting the new game to be a *new game*, navigating the same old caves with the same old enemies and even collecting the same old Udjat Eye is a disillusioning experience. As for what content is new, it uniformly departs from the old design philosophy of predictability. New enemies move more chaotically, are harder to hit, have larger and less-avoidable methods of attack, inflict crippling and difficult to remove new status-effects. Additionally, they are more-densely packed into less-open spaces, multiplying the probability that any misstep results in a wacky chain-reaction of unpreventable fatal damage, especially given that old boons like the jetpack now often become explosive liabilities instead. The final region of the game's normal route embodies this chaotic premise wholeheartedly; a bullet-hell landscape of perpetually-circling fireballs not only turns normal enemies and their corpses into high-speed projectiles fully capable of stunlocking and juggling away whatever amount of health the player has managed to accumulate, but will make cheerful pinball-game sound-effects on each impact to emphasize the whimsical unpredictability of having an exploding UFO chucked at you from offscreen. In Spelunky 1, physics-driven instant death was always a possibility, but even near the end, it was the norm for most hazards to just deal a reasonably proportionate amount of damage and then allow you to act again. In many of Spelunky 2's areas, suffering a hit and 'just' taking damage cannot really be expected.

Making matters worse, the game's chaotic new portfolio of threats is not matched by any improvements in controllability. The slightest variation in D-pad input will still arrest the player's movement on ledges or ladders they had no intention of stopping against or flipping over; the climbing glove in particular frequently spells death in the game's chaotic later areas, introducing deadly undesired pauses into the necessarily-rapid navigation of constantly crushing elevators and eternally-milling fireballs, because the game still insists upon a minimalist control scheme for increasingly demanding platforming challenges; overloading the 'move left or right' control with 'also cling to the wall' just doesn't cut it when you have to sprint through a series of narrow, twisting, moving horizontal-and-vertical passages. Sometimes this insistence on control-minimalism makes very basic actions impossible; suppose an item the player wishes to pick up is located on a 1-tile-wide platform which can be descended through, but there is a rope passing through the platform. The player *cannot* pick up the item, because they cannot crouch on the platform to do so, because the crouch-input navigates the rope instead. But Spelunky 2 wears these clumsinesses with pride; mechanical awkwardness is a proud feature with a long history, not a bug to correct. While not a control scheme issue, this proud embrace of pointless problems is best exemplified by the Hired Hand. 'Rescuing' one of these 'allied' NPCs and attempting to actually traverse the dungeon with their 'help' invariably means being killed shortly thereafter by their wild, reckless attacking and throwing of objects; one learns just to not bother rescuing them, or if they are accidentally released, to simply kill them before moving on rather than to suffer their 'help'. No gameplay function is served by having a 'benefit' that is actually a strict liability, but that's just what kind of punitive-for-its-own-sake gameplay Spelunky 2 thinks it's supposed to be about. 

The first Spelunky was fun. This one just feels tedious. There's little joy, after having one run end due to some offscreen lava-spewing explosion, in setting off again to discover what Kaizo-style configuration of hazards will be thrown together this time. In the first game, losses felt mostly deserved and victory felt achievable with attentiveness and a *little* luck; even the alternate Hell route was enjoyable enough to both discover and to conquer without outside spoilers. In this one it's hard enough to put up with the normal game, much less embrace the even-more-random conditions dictating whether following an alternate route is feasible on a given run. So if you're a punishment-craving veteran of unforgiving precision platformers who doesn't mind intentionally-awkward controls in a game willing to punish anything less than a perfect run, go for it. Otherwise, there are other better games for sale.

Spelunky 2 is a simulation of real life. Everything is finite, nothing good stays that way, and everything you know and love will be gone with one mistake. I am certain this game was created by a demon who wanted to see how much a person could suffer while playing a video game. You will go through this game hundreds, thousands of times and end up failing on the finish line 99% of the time. Any time you slightly mess up, every time you go on autopilot, any time that you think you're safe even for a second and your run is gone and you have to start from the beginning. 

The progression of the game is one of the most convoluted I've ever seen in a video game, but it gives your existence meaning and purpose. No matter how many times you fail, you learn about the game and use that for every advantage you can before you die to utter bullshit. Eventually, every thought will be about Spelunky 2 with it infecting your dreams and causing nightmares. You will watch tip videos on YouTube that will prove that you know nothing and prove that you will do anything to succeed at this game and after many hours of this game you will finally win. Once you win, you feel amazing that despite the odds, despite everyone and everything being out to kill you, it is finally time for you to rest knowing that you beat Spelunky 2. Then you play another run and realize the only reason you won is because the game decided to be generous and not screw you over as you repeat the process.

Such is the fate of anyone who decides to play this stupid game.

Το Spelunly 2 είναι 2d platformer-roguelike τίτλος και ο δεύτερος της σειράς. Γενικά, το παιχνίδι ήταν αρκετά ευχάριστο, αλλά με απογοήτευσε σα sequel, ίσως περίμενα εγώ πολλά δε ξέρω. Σε αυτό το τίτλο η ιστορία είναι ότι η κόρη του πρωταγωνιστή από  το πρώτο παιχνίδι, ψάχνει τους γονείς της που χάθηκαν σε μια εξερεύνηση και πηγαίνεις να τους βρεις. Τα γραφικά και η μουσική πολύ κοντά στο πρώτο αλλά αυτό δεν είναι κάτι που με πείραξε ιδιαίτερα. Ο χειρισμός παραμένει το ίδιο καλός με το προηγούμενο τίτλο. Τα αντικείμενα ήταν ένα από τα αρνητικά για μένα ή πιο σωστά η έλλειψη αυτών. Τα boss ήταν οκ. Τα mobs τα ίδια απλά προστέθηκαν 2-3 ανα κόσμο. Με λίγα λόγια είναι ο ίδιος τίτλος με λίγες προσθήκες, κάτι που προσωπικά με έκανε να νιώθω πως απλά παίζω ένα dlc του πρώτου τίτλου και όχι το νέο τίτλο της σειράς.

Spelunky 2 has grown to be one of my favourite games.
I had a hate- love relationship with Spelunky HD. I loved it for it's greatness and hated it because i couldn't beat it and it always felt like the game defeated me. I eventually let it go without discovering the mystical places i've heard about, like the golden City or Hell.
Spelunky 2 is such a great game because it [i]feels[/i] so good. So precise and alive and organic. Even after hundreds of hours the game still surprises and delights me. The feeling of discovering the deeper levels is very satisfying. 

[i]"The more you play it, the more it becomes yours"[/i] says Derek Yu (creator of the Spelunky series) and that the game "tells stories". I've had a great time playing this game. Alone and especially with friends. Even with strangers on the internet, because the community of this game is mostly super nice. I could smilingly tell a lot of stories from this game.

This game challenged me. A lot. Over and over. All the failed attempts made me change my point of view: [i]"As long as you learn something from it, it's fine to die"[/i] says Derek. This game taught me a lot. In the end i accomplished things, that i never thought were possible for me. I even killed [redacted] and flew into the [redacted]. A few minutes later i was dead. It was glorious. Thanks Derek. I would do it all again.
Step aside blue frogs, moles have taken the lead.

Spelunky 2 is such a great game and an incredible improvement of the first. Items feel easier to use, the multiplayer is flawless, movement is sharp and discovering places and items in the game that you've never seen before is exciting!
It's Spelunky too.

I tried to enjoy the game with my partner but just couldn't. The stun after being hit is so long that if you make a mistake you normally just die. You get hit because the attack range is weird, then you bounce like 10 ft., hit another enemy or trap, bounce again, get hit by the first enemy again and now you're dead. I can't tell you how many times I dropped down to a lower level to immediately get hit by 2 separate arrow traps and then die to some random enemy. Also being able to hit your partner is terrible since the hitboxes aren't great and you bounce like crazy and just end up dying over nothing. I enjoyed the first spelunky, I hate this one. Sorry not sorry.

Day 2 of Spelunking;

I'm miserable, but I must keep going.

I Did not find this game enjoyable at all, there is 0 forgiveness what so ever, and i constantly find myself pissed off because I've told the game to attack something while moving, but instead of the creature getting attacked like id expect, i take damage for being "too close" and the thing i attacked is fine, despite the attack animation starting. i also find that you rarely lose 1 life at a time, more often then not, when you lose a life, something else decides to bulldoze you while you are unable to move, Not to mention that your own projectiles are more dangerous to yourself than the creatures in the dungeon. rocks come bouncing back at you like rubber, Your 20lb lead bombs bounce like a tennis ball on a brick wall, and if one of them happens to hit you, you are K.O before you can even stand up to run away. not to mention your whip is a wopping 1' long... youd be better off grabbing one of the snakes you nearly died to and whipping it around your head like a flail, or the bone of the skeleton that manages to steal 1 of your 4 lives before he even stands up off the ground. yet it takes you 3-4 seconds to even stand up after knocking yourself out with a rock that YOU you threw at a well 4 inches away from you. this game makes you feel like polly pocket stole the man in the yellow hats jacket and fell down the white rabbits hole into madness

Woo boy, this game. Spelunky 2 is basically a drug. Or maybe more like gambling. Each time you die (and you WILL die) you will have to forcefully stop yourself from pressing "Quick Restart" to have any sort of productive day ahead of you. This game will eat up your time. But when you make progress and die later, you are so eager to reach that point again that you throw your cares out the window and play just one more time. And then another becomes another becomes another and eventually it's 11 p.m. and you had work to do today. Oh well. Guess you'll just play yourself to sleep tonight.

God I can't tell you how much I wanted to put off this review, it feels as I'm writing it as if I'm saying goodbye to something I love. Of course I'm not doing that, I'm still gonna play Spelunky 2, and alot of it. But still something feels wrong about reviewing it. Like I'm sending something away, I honestly shouldn't feel that way because it's a game and this is a review. But... after 177 hours... it just feels wrong like I truly cannot put into words how good this game is. 

It's 177 hours of something I love, something I'm passionate about. This game will beat you down, it will humble you, it will hit you like a whip with RNG so awful it makes eve the most RNG centric games want to throw up. But it never stops encouraging you to push forward, to learn, and to grow. With this game comes a mix of optimism but a moment to learn humility and replace over-confidence with a respectable amount of confidence.

And this game is just fun, whether it be the memes, the community surrounding it, the developers, or the game itself you'll find yourself having pure fun.

I waited until I was finished with all achievements to do this review, so I have done basically everything except for 7-99 although I am currently trying to start on the C.O. runs (PB is currently 7-6). I will miss going for those achievements, they kept me on my feet (that darn Eggplant run!) and I will miss the grind of the last few runs.

I don't have much more to say, not because there isn't more to say, but because I'm generally not a good reviewer and words are hard. So here's the gist. Buy this game, learn it, and learn from it. You won't regret it, it's that good.

Thank you Mossmouth, you've truly outdone yourselves.

[table]
    [tr]
        [th]Factor[/th]
        [th]Rating[/th]
	[th]Description[/th]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Gameplay Loop[/td]
        [td]6[/td]
	[td]Spelunky 2 did feel like a worthy sequel to a pretty much perfect game when I first started. New kinds of worlds, completely fresh enemy types, improvements to a lot of things about the game, the addition of so many more elements, branching paths, secrets that IDK how long it's gonna take to find. While no sequel can be as fresh as the original - this one does as much as possible to achieve that. BUT - and I am adding this after a year and a half later to give it a 6 instead of 10 because I think the loop of Spelunky is much better than 2. The fact that there's a boss fight after the first world every time can get tedious. Same with the Olmec boss fight being too early. But the biggest gripe I have is with the game being too long. An everyday Spelunky run was 20ish minutes and change, and Spelunky 2 feels double that. You might say why's that a huge deal? It's because death in this game is instant for very short mistakes, and that only feels good when the runs are very quick to lose, but also win. A lot of patterns also seem much more standardized and flattened. While I do appreciate being able to be forgiven by the shopkeeper, and the mechanical ugprades - there's def a lot I'd pick in the first game that were executed much better. My ideal Spelunky would be the one with the design and music of the first, with mechanics and polish of the second.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Narrative[/td]
        [td]-[/td]
	[td]Not really a narrative other than an intro from what I've seen. But I might update this if I find out that's not the case.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Visuals[/td]
        [td]7[/td]
	[td]I REALLY dig the aesthetic design of the Spelunky games. It's actually what drew me towards Spelunky 1 as well. And during the development process, Spelunky 2 wasn't looking as good to me and I'd decided to not pick it up because of that. But it turned out looking better than HD! Much more detailed, yet still maintaining simplicity. Every enemy, object or trap pops right out of an already vibrant backdrop, while every new world feels and looks completely different from the last. But I do hope they made some of the things optional, like the green hoop effect every time you jump wearing spring shoes etc. I do find the spike traps kinda hard to spot as they look very similar to normal blocks. They don't stand out as much. The biggest bane of all though, are the bear traps which sometimes spawn in bushes - becoming completely invisible. Then there's the pink colored spikes in a certain world which blend right into everything else. TBH I don't like the visual design of that whole world itself. But overall still a solid 7/10 for me.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Mechanics[/td]
        [td]10[/td]
	[td]Another thing I was skeptical about. How are they going to improve upon an already polished game in the mechanical aspect. But they found little things I didn't know I wanted, and brought those changes. For example, the climbing gloves made you get stuck on a certain surface which could be helpful but also disastrous in Spelunky 1. Now they only work when you hold that direction. This simple change brings the control into the player's hands. The cape that's used to glide was a toggle button prompt, but now it's hold and I can see the difference it makes and the flexibility it adds. The hitbox is even more higher, and the movement is just as fluid and fast paced. The addition of liquid mechanics is a game changer and brings a lot of variety into the gameplay. I don't say this a lot, but nailed it.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Challenge[/td]
        [td]6[/td]
	[td]While it retains the identity of Spelunky still, the longer gameplay loop and just "more stuff" kinda waters up the overall focused challenge a little bit for. Still great though. Spelunky 1 had me doing quick, 10 minute runs, because you could finish the game really quickly but also die quickly. In this, dying is just as quick but you don't finish it quick.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Variety[/td]
        [td]7[/td]
	[td]On paper, there's just so much more than Spelunky here. Mounts, the 2nd layer, branching paths, more areas, MORE everything. And hence when I started I put a 9/10 here, but now I've come to realize that the runs actually get much more samey in this than the previous. The first area has no variety at all, and has very repeating patterns. Then you fight the same boss the same way, do the same things and it feels much more "standardized", down to finding the henchmen. Feels much more designed for speedrunners than for just the random wackiness that I came to appreciate in the first. Things like the Moon challenge and the similar one later felt great the first few times around but now I just find myself skipping them because of the tedium. Similar is the case with many of the game's mechanics.  [/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Mapping[/td]
        [td]6[/td]
	[td]Derek Yu has got randomly generated worlds feeling like handcrafted ones down to a science - literally. No roguelike other than Spelunky makes levels feel so different each time. Not even Spelunky 2. Yep. I do think the levels tend to get a little too samey in 2 than they did in 1, for some reason. [/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Sound[/td]
        [td]5[/td]
	[td]Some enemies have a sound signature before they attack you, which is great. I do find the sound of the boomerang, spring shoes, jetpack, etc. to be very jarring personally, standing out instead of blending in. Udjat eye blinking isn't distinct enough and can be confused with the monkeys sound. The most disappointing thing about the game though, is that the music is just mediocre. The first game had god tier track after god tier track, the next more memorable than the last. Here it's pretty forgettable elevator music for the most part. [/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Interface[/td]
        [td]8[/td]
	[td]The interface is a clear improvement over the previous game. It's cleaner. It doesn't block out elements in-game. It shows PS4 icons rather than just the Xbox ones like the previous ones (even though I use the keyboard 90% of the time anyway). There is a much required "Quick Restart" option added. But I still have one solid gripe with it. They removed the option of "Quick Start" that showed up as soon the game boot up. It allowed you to get right into the action. But now you need to skip through 3 menus/cutscenes, then watch a rope descend animation, and then another animation every time you open the game. Would've liked that to be optional. Apart from that, pretty much everything is better.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Pricing & Performance[/td]
        [td]8[/td]
	[td]Great for full price, even. Performance has issues on weaker PCs but they've fixed a lot since release.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Replay Value [/td]
        [td]10[/td]
	[td]Need I say anything? I've been on and off - playing Spelunky HD since the day I bought it to this day. I see myself playing this for years now as well. This is going to be my go-to "pick up and play" game and due to the quick runs - has excellent replay value.[/td]
    [/tr]

    [tr]
        [td]Online (Not part of final score)[/td]
        [td]-[/td]
	[td]Not tried[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]DLC (Not part of final score)[/td]
        [td]-[/td]
	[td]-[/td]
    [/tr]
[/table]

This is a really hard game, and very punishing, but it's also really nice. While it's hard the difficulty is adjusted by your objectives. Want to just beat the game? Good luck, it'll take a while but you'll do it reliably with some effort. Want to get the hard ending? It's reasonably harder, but you'll be ready for most of it once you have to do it. Want to get the special ending? Good Luck. That's all. It's a challenge ridiculously hard and long, but you'll enjoy the way.

The painful learning combined with the extremely satisfying progression will keep you coming back for more!  Multiplayer is hilarious and i'm so glad they added it as a Spelunky HD player.  Guides via YouTube are recommended when you start to progress further as the community has spent a ton of time learning the ins and outs of this game for you. Okay, it's taken me a LONG time to get to this review.  Note that I have more time with this one than it seems, as I also have the console version.  I'd thought of writing this awhile ago, but... well, it was hard to quite nail down what I thought of this one.

Thing is, I think Spelunky 2 is a good game, but... disappointing at the same time.  Look, I'm sorry, this does NOT feel like a sequel to me.  This feels like a really bizarre DLC for the previous game that, instead of ADDING content, just REPLACED a bunch of it.  That's seriously what it feels like.

Now, that might be fine if this game had GENUINE mod support, but it doesnt... so there's no Workshop to shore up the game's limited content.

And indeed, "limited" is how I'd put it.  Well... for the main route anyway.  Thing is, the devs went waaaaayyyyyyyyyy overboard with the stupid secrets, adding next to no content for the actual "main" route.  Item variety in particular was REALLY bad in the previous game... I cant think of another roguelike with such little item variety... and it's pretty much the same here.  Oh, there ARE a whole bunch of items that got added... and they're almost all exclusive to the game's overblown secrets.  This is a trend that keeps up all the way through... it aint just the items.

The "alternate paths" dont really help, either, as they're horribly unbalanced.  The Jungle, for instance... there's zero reason to go there, and if you've played this enough, you know exactly why.  The Temple is... not much better.  I was hoping for the game to present me with a tough choice each time I got to a branching path, but... it never does that.  I pick the same route.  Every time.  Because I cant see an actual good reason to ever do otherwise.

And the secret stuff is... look, I'll be honest.  I hate it.  I *HATE* it.  All of it.  Now, to be fair, I didnt expect to like that part of the game.  I absolutely LOATHED the entire secret "path" in the first game... I did a Hell run once and only once, managed to beat it on the first try (after all, once you learn how to steal in HD, you're pretty much unstoppable), and declared that I'd never, EVER even consider trying it again.   Somehow, the sequel's secrets manage to be even more annoying, which is... baffling.  Oh, dont get me wrong:  It's not a matter of "OMG it's too hard".  I've only made an actual attempt at [REDACTED] a few times, and out of those few times, when I screwed it up it was generally because I went in the wrong bloody door on a certain special stage.  While I havent beaten the true final boss yet, well... at the rate I've progressed, it wont be much longer (if I bother to keep trying it, anyway).  But... I dont really WANT to do any of that.  It's not much fun, and never feels rewarding to me... just irritating.  Plus, like in the first game, no matter what fun items you may be carrying with you, you WILL have to drop them at a certain point to instead carry secret-related items.  Run variety, already lacking, plummets off a cliff when doing the secret route.

And I know that Derek has stated that the game is not really meant to be something that you feel you NEED to "fully" beat, that it's more about the experience, which I can appreciate, but... as a lot of players know, something about it makes the whole thing just feel incomplete if you ARENT trying to do that.  Which I think is due to the low content variety in the main path... it's hard to say for sure, but the game absolutely gives that feeling, considering that half the bloody content is locked behind secrets.

Also the boss fights are just as bad as they were in the previous games... much of the time, they arent "fights" so much as "massacre them in 5 seconds".  There's one specific exception early on, but for the most part, they're all like that.

That's not to say that the game is bad... it isnt.  It's still good.  The core gameplay of the series is just as good as ever... movement and basic mechanics are still excellent, the game is still chaotic while never being TRULY unfair (usually) and hilarious things happen all the time.  It's still Spelunky.

And some things really did get improved.  One thing that bugged me about the previous game was that shops were bloody stupid.  The choice of whether to steal or not should be a tough one, but once you knew the method (which was stupid easy) you'd ALWAYS do it.  Always.  Because you were bloody invincible once you did.  It was horribly unbalanced and playing WITHOUT stealing tended to feel VERY lacking.  Here though, they changed... something.  I'm not too clear on WHAT they did, but going the non-crime route is just as valid as doing the murder thing.  Shops are a lot more interesting now and personal playstyle comes into play a lot more.  I very much appreciate that bit.  They brought back the dice game, too. And while there may not be a whole LOT of content, what IS there feels waaaaaaayyyyyyyyy more refined than in the previous game.  It's all just BETTER (except the bosses).  Granted, some things can feel frustrating at first (moles) but once you get the hang of them... you see that it all really does work well.

Heck, even the Hired Hands are better (drastically better AI).  I never, ever bothered with those guys in the previous game, because duh.  But here?  I'll USUALLY free them.  Their psychotic rampages often murder the funky heck outta enemies so I dont have to, and I've yet to have one get me killed.  These guys are way more fun than before, that's for sure.  So that's good.

Really I just wish there was MORE.  Or, that there were mods.  And yes, I know, there ARE mods, but as the game doesnt have innate support, there arent all that many as there COULD be as they are harder to make (still some cool ones out there though).

The game really is darned good, despite all that I've said... it's just that it could have been a bloody masterpiece.  If half the freaking content hadnt been locked behind secrets, anyway.  But hey, that's just me... if you LIKE secrets in games like this, you might enjoy it a lot more than I do.  There's definitely an element of personal preference in there.

spelunky 2 is a great game with a profound development and within its formula. the first game is great, it compiles different mechanics and content together into a rich experience where its main strength comes from replayability and a fresh spin on the roguelike genre.  but with the sequel, everything is several times more sensitive, this is a direct result from making spelunky 2 several times more bigger than spelunky hd. usually, when games expand in a natural and organic way, its an objective improvement. the problem is that because of how the spelunky format is designed. how the difficulty is designed is like pacman where most enemies and mechanics a minor obstacles but when combined, is overwhelming and build up a difficulty curve. meaning that most of your experience in spelunky is unscripted and therefore always unique. and with expanding gameplay in spelunky 2, you get even more unique. but the only problem is that because of the wide expansion, the gameplay can sometimes be extremely overwhelming. situations can range from moderate to sometimes completely unfair or almost impossible, this almost always happens to this new stun lock mechanic they introduced when you get hit in the air. its only a side effect from making a bigger game its just a fatal flaw a person should understand before starting to play this game. don't get me wrong i love this game. please don't take this as a full game review, this review is just a way for me to convey the what not anybody I've seen talk about i feel is important to most audiences.  please comment if you have any thoughts or critisism, I'm always looking to improve my perspective and personal opinion.

I was hearing loads of good things about Spelunky 2, thought "oh, I feel like I never really gave the first one a fair go, I should pick that up" and within a couple of hours remembered why I dropped the first one so fast.

I played this for an hour and a half, died about 70-80 times, and found the whole experience absolutely infuriating. The puny jump, the fact most traps will one- or two-hit kill you, the lack of guidance to the systems that aren't necessarily that complicated but are generally quite opaque.

By the end I pretty much always knew what had killed me and had often seen it before it did so, but it wasn't a particularly fun experience, mostly because it didn't feel that rewarding.

I tend to think of myself as a very patient, iterative person, but this really was a bridge too far for me.

Yeah, it's hard, it's hard as all hell. It's a rogue-like, what else do you expect?

But that doesn't make it less enjoyable, since the new online multiplayer has made teaching it way easier, which reduces the learning curve. Just find a friend or two to play with and you'll figure it out, I'm still learning 12 hours in, I haven't made it past 2-1 yet.

EDIT (54 hours in) - am yet to make it past 3-1 without shortcuts. this game cuts my soul like butter. please end my suffering.
EDIT 2 (67 hours in) - am yet to make it past 5-1 without shortcuts. I'M CLIMBING THE GODDAMN LADDER
EDIT 3 (130 hours in) - I am complete, I do not give a single sh*t about all the secrets. This is because I am sorta tired of spikes and moles and spined lizards and witch doctors and magmas and punch-trap combos. Sigh. I beat "the game", with no shortcuts (though I never even made it there with shortcuts anyways). Finally. That is all I care about. I have reached what I see as the top of the ladder, I know I can stand on parts of the ladder that aren't meant to be supporting human weight, that many might say you haven't gotten to the absolute height without standing on it, but I don't really want to suffer any longer. If you thought I didn't like this game because of how much I talk cr*p about it, then you would be wrong. This is just a very well made, really hard, REALLY hard game. And I am just not use to hard games. have a good one.
EDIT 4 (424 hours in) - AAH!! This game has corrupted me... I must 100%... but I don't know if I have the strength to do it. The Low-Scorer Achievement causes me actual IRL suffering. I have cried dying to the end boss with no gold. I was so close.

After completing the achievements set out by the lord I, the acolyte, was divinely given the will to make the pilgrimage to the holy 7-99. Given this task attempts had begun with glee and ignorant hope. As those attempts mounted the hands conducted symphonies, the brain pumped refined electricity and the eyes saw the future. But this is merely all that is required to get to the gates of the holy land. The real test requires focus, but not just mere intellectual focus, it requires a focus that can change the direction of wind, slow time and bend light. A century of hours had passed and this fact had become clear to the jaded mind. At that point describing a controller as a "controller" would be unfitting for it might as well be made of flesh. The eyes no longer saw a screen for the display was etched into the fibre of each ticking part of the brain. This however was still not enough, for this crusade aims not for revelation but a metamorphosis of holy gaming knowledge. At the current moment there is no screen, controller, hand, brain, eyes. The only thing left: just "is". Everything is reduced to fundamentals, there is no separation, and therefor only one thing to know; what are those caveman talking about? Yes, for the wisdom of the caveman is the wisdom of the gods and the wisdom of all. For the deepest cosmic depths my meditation can take me the caveman walks and will continue to walk on that forsaken earth. After many hours of strife the final stage of metamorphosis can finally begin. To reach the heights of the all that is 7-99 one must first reach the zen of the caveman who was there at the start and will inevitably be there at the end; pogging.

If you're familiar with the first Spelunky, this game will be extremely fascinating and addicting to play. If you aren't so familiar with the franchise, I suggest reading up on it or playing the first game first. In doing so, this will provide with the necessary foundations and backstory to understand whats going on to a full extent. It will also give you some time to adapt to the mechanics and play-style as Spelunky 2 can be quite hard if you don't know what you're doing. To summarise, this game is extremely fun and addicting to play and holds many secrets to explore. I highly recommend to everyone interested in platform games. As long as you have some idea of what you are getting into (many...many...many hours of frustration and constant disappointment), this game will be awesome to you!

My first impression of this game was... mixed. I have a friend who played it a lot, but I really wasn't interested in a simple platformer with cartoon like animation. It wasn't until after I did ila few runs with via remote play that I actually got an idea of this game, and decided to buy it myself.

The game is challenging, and you will die a lot. A LOT. But it's rewarding in its own way. I remember how proud I felt when I could consistently get to the end of the 4th level, and later floors one through four were breeze and I could get as far as the 10th level without a problem, and later near the end of the game (of the normal run, that is). The challenge this game creates is what has brought me back time and time again, the constant failure is what drove me to play and become better. In the end, it becomes a game of not making it to the end, but doing well in the game; finishing with style and prowess.

On top of that, there is a lot more to the game than meets the eye. Secrets, lore (even if it doesn't all make sense), and the things to uncover. Seriously, the wiki for this game is far larger than I thought it would be.

So, if you're looking for a game that will challenge you, or where you and your friends can die in the most hilarious of ways, this one I highly recommend. And for $20, I say go for it. It's worth the cost. I mean, what else are you going to spend it on? A couple of pizzas? Putting gas in your car so you can make it to that job interview? Unimportant, compared to this game.

This game has my thumbs up.
-Llanon



P. S. though, if you actually do have a job interview, you probably should prioritize that and use your $20 there, just saying.

I love the Spelunky HD, and was anxious for Spelunky 2.

I made many mistakes, and died a lot. It took me hundreds hours to kill the first final boss, and many more for the last boss, and reachede the final area after more than a year playing.
This game has more options and more quests than the first one, but still take you to the same place.

I recommend this game to anyone who doesn't care with repetitions and likes to suffer. :)

Huge kudos to Mr. Yu for developing a great sequel to a great game that almost single-handedly brought about the genre of roguelike. You're going to die a lot. Like a lot a lot. You'll be gently brushed by bats, spiders, moles, lizards and cavemen before being crushed to death, exploded, burnt, eaten and more.

Like the first game, each death is a lesson. If you mess up once it can all come to an abrupt end in an instant. But that's where the appeal comes from. There's secrets galore to uncover and mastering the game takes a lot of grit, focus and effort.

Play solo, or with friends online in adventure or arena mode or try your luck at the daily challenge. Whichever you choose, you'll be tested.

Short version: I do not recommend this game to anyone who loved the prequel.

Long version: I've been playing the prequel (Spelunky HD) for years (just shy of 2000 hours on Steam) and love it. I still play it a lot, try to beat the daily challenge every day and use it to kill time and hone my skills still. This Game does a pretty shitty job as a successor in my opinion and this is due to various causes. For instance, the controls are wonky and awkward. Where the prequel allowed you to precisely control your character, use every millimeter of every movement, this one is just different. It always feels like the character is drunk or kind of "sticks" to the ground, every jump feels awkward and just wrong. Enemies' hitboxes seem all over the place, sometimes the whip misses although you're standing right next to your target which is really annoying. I bought this game enthusiastically when it came out and expected a worthy successor to one of my favourite games ever, but I was very disappointed to learn that Spelunky 2 is a completely different game. I do not find it hard from a difficulty point of view, but it next to impossible to do anything right with these wonky controls and game design.

All in all, I am very disappointed and would not recommend this game at all.

If you're into side-scrolling platformers, this game is perfection. Understand that it's flipping HARD. But that's not due to poor controls or bad level design that so many games in the genre suffer from. Spelunky 2 is crisp. This game towers above the other popular rogue-likes of today because its difficulty translates into a more rewarding experience. You're not going to retain your xp after you die. You don't get to keep your perks or inventory. When you die, you start over from the beginning. So this isn't a game where you can mundanely farm xp until your character is strong enough to succeed. Success in Spelunky comes from reflexes and decision-making. This game is the pinnacle of fun in gaming.

It's fun but here are a few caveats that imo are game ruining. 

Firstly, the mole enemies are ridiculous, annoying, and unfair. So many runs would end because some random mole enemy would jump onto the screen from above or to the side of you without much or any warning and my character would take damage, it feels very broken. It isn't a fun game mechanic to play around and it encourages the player to have a slow approach. 
Second, the tile in the forest biome that kills you instantly looks almost identical to a regular tile. If it kills you instantly regardless of your health, surely there can be something to differentiate it from other tiles.
Lastly, when you take any damage, you are unable to move. You're still able to take damage though, so this leads to a succession of hits by one enemy, or you just being juggled by enemies and there's nothing you can do about it.

It is hard for me to be invested in each run when you can die so undeservedly and it makes me reluctant to play, otherwise the game is really fun.

i am in pain

Spelunky 2 is probably my favorite game on steam. It's the game I have the most hours in, the game i play most with friends, and the game I enjoy the most, but that doesn't mean it's perfect.


Spelunky 2 is a difficult game, and in the 60 hours that I have played this game, I have never beaten it in a non seeded run. I was able to beat it once with this seed: 2EDB3B4F, but that doesn't matter. The dwellings (first world) is brutal, with moles that come out of the walls, and lizards that can send you flying into corners just to get hit again, as well as bats, which are hard to hit from below, unless you know the backswing of your whip. I don't remember how long it took me to consistantly be able to get out of the dwellings but it was a while. The game doesn't have permanent upgrades, other than shortcuts to help you get to later parts of the game without going through the earlier parts, although if your going for secret endings and collectable stuff, you're going to need to start from the beginning either way. 

I think the level generation is alright, to me dwelling has too many repeating structures, but the rest of the levels all feel unique in each seed. Speaking of seeds, the game supports a seeded run mode (as mentioned earlier) but there is no current way to find what seed you just played in a normal run, so if you want to discover new seeds, select a random seed in seeded mode and just do that on repeat until you get a seed you like. 

The controls feel great, it's just fast enough to feel quick and fast paced, but not so fast that you feel like you're losing control of your character. The whip feels nice and heavy, with a small backlash behind and slightly above you before the main hitbox comes out, and it's really satisfying to time it right to hit bats above you, or maybe block incoming arrow traps. You can run, jump, pick up and throw stuff, and use ropes and bombs, all of which are fun to do.

Overall, I think the game is great, and only has a few low points. I think compared to the original, this game has a lot more BS. The hit stun is much longer, making it MUCH easier to get combo'd to death no matter how much heath you're at. The moles are just annoying in my opinion, and same goes for those stupid lizards, but hey the BS goes down after the dwelling. Getting past that first world may be annoying for new players, but once you do, you'll get the hang of it. I think the BS of the dwelling readies you for the game, really punishing you for pretty much everything, giving extreme examples of stuff that could happen in the later levels, and teaching you to be careful.

Overall, I'd give the game a 9/10, if it weren't for that kinda dumb first world, it would be a 10 in my opinion.

Before I go, I'd like to mention one thing, mods are really fun, and you should checkout spelunky.fyi for tons of fun mods, whether it be simple custom characters, or full on randomizers, although some do give you achievements you didn't actually earn. I only got the cosmic ocean from a randomizer, but steam still thinks I did it :|

Like Spelunky 1, Spelunky 2 provides a fun and challenging rouge-like experience. That being said, though, this is a sequel that originally didn't grip me quite like Spelunky 1 but has grown on me. Overall I'd say it succeeded in improving the gameplay but failed in capturing the same boisterous and exciting energy of the first one (mostly due to the OST being so uninspired). It's got the same tight movement and controlling your character feels just as good if not better than the first one and that combined with the addition of a much steeper challenge to beat makes this a must-buy for anyone who fell in love with the first game.

To sum this game up quick, It's a really fun learning curve. Spelunky 2 will send you down an ever expanding cave with only one goal, get all the way to the end;  and whether you like it or not, your going to have to learn somethings along the way. Spelunky 2 is a game that gives you know checkpoints and changes the layout of levels as you play; what this does is present you with new levels every time you play, so that if you want to get far your going to have to learn the mechanics or die trying. By presenting you with no real fail save for when you die Spelunky 2 promotes you to thin critically and learn from your mistakes, getting you a little bit closer to the finish line with every death, and with every discovery. 
I really recommend this game to anyone who likes a good platforming challenge!

Hi!
Do you like pain? Suffering even? Are you a masochist but too introverted to go out and find yourself a big titty goth mommy gf to crush your head like a watermelon between your thighs? What if you wanted something that you can sink your time in to whether it's 20 minutes or 4 hours?

This little box of horrors is a well veiled menagerie of torture behind a well animated and drawn cast of characters and obstacles. The platforming of the game is wonderfully brutal and buttery smooth. The fact every run starts the same and has different scenery through the levels means that the only thing you can do to improve your gameplay is to GET GUD.
Would I recommend this game to my friends? Absolutely! Schadenfreude is one HELL of a drug. But in reality, whether single player or multi-player, there are some hilarious interactions that make me scratch my head to wonder how the stars aligned to murder me so.
Endlessly replayable. I'm still finding new tricks and interactions 500 hours in

-- Praise
This game is great if you want a real challenge coming from the original games and I would highly recommend it to anyone looking for something that they will have to learn and master to overcome its challenges.
-
The areas have alot of variety and can be fun to go through.
-
The challenges thrown at you are highly varied throughout the game.
-
Deathmatch is far better and more expanded on than Spelunky HD.
-
Online multiplayer works great and is really enjoyable.

-- Complaints.
The game is FAR more difficult than the first game and feels made more for those who have already played the first game.
-
Although it can still be enjoyed by newcomers its much harder to get far with friends and family who want to play more casually.
-
In Spelunky HD where the first area was easy to learn and prepared you for the next levels, Spelunky 2 the first area feels harder than the next areas strait after it and can quickly end adventures before they really start.
-
My biggest gripe with Spelunky 2 is the lack of secret areas that dont require a chain of items/events to go into,
in Spelunky HD most secret areas could be accessed by simply figuring them out through experimentation, 
but in Spelunky 2 most of the secret areas of the game require you to repeat many steps throughout the game becoming more repetitive making them lose their charm.

Which I understand that this was a reference to the true ending of Spelunky HD being expanded on,
but I wish more focus was put onto the minor secrets which would make you explore the dynamic systems rather than mostly just the "true ending" ones that require you to repeat the same steps each game to visit them. 

-- Graphics:
As for the graphics they look great and match the game well.

Though I personally miss the "Indiania Jones" feel of Spelunky HD this game brings its own appealing art style 
that feels good.

-- Soundtrack:
The music was ok at best, but honestly felt generic and repetitive most of the time.

Not close a good as the Spelunky HDs soundtrack which gave great feelings of mystery, exploration, and intensity in its levels and were went with the levels theme perfectly.

In a vacuum, this game is easily good enough to get a thumbs up. The problem is, that for newcomers and fans of the original alike, my advice is "Your better off sticking with the original."
Basically, there are 2 things that differentiate this game from the original. One good, one bad. Sadly, the bad outweighs the good.
The good is that there is a branching level path. At the end of World 1 and World 3, there is a split in the path, so you can proceed to worlds 2a, 2b, 4a or 4b to bring some variety to the table.
The bad thing is that the game is predictable. The original gave you  a grab bag of different tools to gather from the shop, which made each run feel different from the last as you improvised your way forward.
Those tools are still present, but there are new features you can consistently rely on. Every level has a dog and a ghost pot, which optimally you just carry to the end of the level for extra health, and extra money respectively. But you can only hold 1 item at a time, which makes this tedious. And even worse if you want to grad another holdable item to bring with you. Sometimes, there will be a golden idol in a trap, that you also want to bring to the exit or shopkeeper, which again, just makes the errand running back and forth worse.
Levels 1-2 will have either the udjat eye, another carry item from A to B quest, or wild turkeys. 1-3 will have the other scenaria. Wild turkeys can be bombed or otherwise cooked for extra health, or ridden to enable a double jump and slow falling until they take too much damage and die. Then when they die, you bomb them for extra health. If you're feeling adventurous, you can kill turkey fetish man to grab an extra turkey and some extra treasure. You really shouldn't give him the turkeys though, as they're just more useful than his rewards.
The really big problem with the turkeys is that they largely invalidate many of the items that you would ordinarily have to rely on. The double jump means you need to use far fewer ropes, or the climbing glove, and straight up don't need the spring shoes. The slow falling renders the cape redundant unless you switch mounts or your turkey dies. And since you have access to these every run, the items they invalidate rarely have time to shine. Oh, also, the spike shoes don't work while you're on a turkey.
The game is still a tough as nails fun roguelike platformer. But the predictability really kills the strengths of the roguelike genre. The original did not have this particular issue. Both will kill you a lot though, in a mix of fair and unfair manners. I want to say Spelunky 2 is substantially harder, but it's been long enough since I played the original that I can't say for sure.

Six years of practice in Spelunky 1 has finally paid off. I don't die to bats anymore! Now, I die to lizards and moles. Damn it, Derek!

EDIT: After beating hard ending on around 230 hours mark and many great QoL updates, I can safely say that this is the best game ever made for me. It hits everything that I love: randomly generated levels each run that always keep me on my toes, no in-game progression that makes my win purely based on my skill and a little bit of luck, and simple mechanics that chain together into a hard, but winnable challenge.

What I dislike on many modern roguelike games are in-game unlockables that makes the character stronger, thus giving an illusion of the players become significantly much better, even though their skills only increase a little. Spelunky will make sure that each challenge that you overcome are the result of you learning from past failures, correct threat identification, and correct response to such threat. You will feel your own skills increasing as you beat the seemingly insane and impossible challenge.

This game may frustrate many players. I can understand that. Due to random nature of the game, sometimes Spelunky just throw a few bullsht at you that you can't respond in time. I too had my fury with this game's bullsht in the past. It's also because it's the first time someone encounter a particular threat. But, most of the time, it's due to the players' own folly. Taking things slow (most importantly, by changing the default movement into "walk" instead of "run"), identifying threats, and act accordingly, are the only things that you need to beat normal ending every time. Hard ending is entirely a different thing, though, and only players who truly enjoy Spelunky will attempt doing that.

If you can't imagine enduring Spelunky by yourself, good news, Spelunky online multiplayer is ready and great to use. Find yourself a friend or two or three and try to beat the game together! It may make the game slightly easier, but everything is much more fun with friends and you can all laugh at your undoing together. You don't have friend to play with? Go to discord.gg/spelunky and find someone to play with there.

In conclusion, Spelunky 2 is a worthy successor to Spelunky HD and a testament to Spelunky's game design. This is the best game ever for me and I truly recommend it for anyone looking for a pure challenge.

I was extremely excited for this game! The previous Spelunky HD is one of my all time favorites, and my gold standard for modern roguelike games. I can understand that Derek Yu wanted to make his sequel more challenging, but Spelunky 2 goes way too far with it, to the point that it isn't even close to fair anymore. 

But to be fair, the game does some things better than its predecessor, and I wanna list some stuff off, both good and bad.

There's lots of new characters! Each character has a unique kind of rope that they use, which is a nice touch. I also really like the newer character designs and the big influx of new characters to unlock. 

I like the new golden idol altars in zone 1 more than in the original. The giant pillar is much more manageable than a giant wild card boulder of death that could easily ruin a run by crashing into a shop or a vault far off screen from you.

There are many more zones to explore this time. Not only that, there are two different paths you can take at the end of zone 1! I love that! 

I love the turkeys and other mounts that you can use and even keep between floors. Those are cute and I love them.

There are now mini game shops that let you enter a special challenge room where you can earn money and prizes. Sweet!

As for the bad things....

Moles are an obnoxious new enemy that can chase you through walls and floors. I've lost count of how many times they've dropped on me from seemingly out of nowhere because I can't see everywhere at once, or I ended up stuck between a gopher and another hazard and couldn't avoid taking damage because I can't watch the the whole screen.

There is a now an equivalent to the tiki trap that shows up in zone 1, and that's pretty neat! But the arrow traps are now 2 or 3 times as frequent as before. Staying on alert for them means you basically can't ever stop being paranoid about them. The first one wasn't nearly this stressful about that. 

Enemies are far more frequent now, and avoiding one enemy very frequently leads you straight into something else. 
 
The first zone has an actual boss enemy that will very easily instantly kill if you aren't extremely careful, and that got old really fast. 

Sometimes a level will just randomly be HUGE. That wouldn't necessarily be a big problem on its own, except...

The ghost in this game is much more punishing for players who want to explore a bit. And the thing is, it already WAS punishing for players in the last game. It's just even more so now. It now splits into multiple faster ghosts if you aren't quick to get out when it arrives. The previous game already didn't really give you that much freedom to explore levels, so this change seems needlessly aggressive. I could see this being a feature in a version of the game meant to challenge speedrunners, but having it in normal runs seems cruel. 

This game feels a lot like one of those "insane brutal challenge designed to make children cry" challenge mods made for the most dedicated fans of a game. Except that's just the standard game here. And its just not that fun to me. 

This would be a whole other thing if the game had a difficulty option, and this were merely the hard mode. But there isn't an option to make any of this less of a chore.

I gave it my best try! But I just can't justify playing it anymore. I sank over 600 hours of my life into the previous game, and I had a blast with it. I'm putting Spelunky 2 down after 30, because it's just not worth playing any more.

EDIT:

I am aware that a lot of the things that made dwelling unfun have now been since patched such as mole iframes, arrow whipping w/ platform descending etc. 

The area is considerably less grating than when the game was first released. I do still stand by the zone being overall bland with its lack of variety (variety that Mines from Spelunky HD had in spades) and formulaic progression. Udjat Eye spawns can be quite frustrating if the key spawns at the bottom of the map and the chest at the top but overall dwelling does feel better and will be less punishing to new players so I will change this review to a recommend, I have accrued over 100 hours in it after all, so I have got my money's worth and I'm sure others will too. 

I will note that I am still a little bit disappointed by Spelunky 2, particularly by the soundtrack and the variety/formulaic nature of a given run, but that is just me.


Everything below this point is from how the game was over a year ago and has since had many patches. Some content is not relevant anymore.
--------------------------------------------------------------------



Heading into Spelunky 2 off the back of hundreds of hours of HD has been great fun and I love a lot of the new mechanics and features, the new shops, optional quests, the back layer, fluid physics etc but I feel like your average person won't find enjoyment from Spelunky 2 for reasons I will detail below

Dwelling, the first stage. I'll split these issues into 3 categories

1/3 Formulaic progression from 1:1 to 1:4
This area is absolutely far too busy and more often than not is extremely unfun and unrewarding. 1:1-1:4 is practically the same everytime save you may find an alter or dark level, and the Key/Yang optional quest may alternate between 1:2 and 1:3. For a game like spelunky this repeating formulae doesn't work and results in very boring, time consuming gameplay which honestly just feels like a chore. I realise the turkeys are optional but the health they give for blowing them up is pretty important considering the difficulty of Dwelling. The further levels do not have this issue really at all. The Quillback fight is incredibly repetitive once you've done it a few times and doesn't need to be a guaranteed event.

2/3 Resource rarity and too resource consuming:
The terrain generation on dwelling is extremely punishing in that you practically have to use all your resources to get around, there's many areas where it's completely impossible to scale back up the level without sacrificing ropes. it's not uncommon to have to use 2 ropes and a bomb or two to get Udjat eye. This wouldn't be so much of an issue if crates weren't so rare. It feels like there's maybe a quarter of the crates you got in this level's equivalent in Spelunky HD and even then crates weren't incredibly common. This wouldn't be a problem (and isn't) if this type of resource consuming level generation was saved for later in the game when you have established a run with resources to spare. 

3/3 The sheer amount of mobs, arrow traps + moles and lizards
Dwelling practically plays out like a Spelunky HD Frozlunky Sashavole generation mod, you'll know what I mean if you've played it. The amount of mobs you can see at any one point in the area is far too high, especially considering the moles which have 3 health and can move through blocks + the lizards which also have 3 health and whilst aren't terribly hard to avoid are still very time consuming and frustrating to deal with. I don't know why Derek/The development team decided to add 2 new mobs both of which have 3 health as it breaks down the pacing of this first stage quite a bit. On top of this, moles seem to have iframes when moving in and out of blocks (I've not tried with explosives as bombs are precious on the first area). Additionally there's also an insane amount of arrow traps, it's not uncommon to see 2 arrow traps pointing directly in the area of your spawn from the getgo, and there's plenty of traps which cannot be dealt with via arrow whipping due to their placement which further breaks the pacing as you have to go find an item to set them off.

Also, the music for Dwelling can get incredibly grating and is generally slightly disappointing when compared to Spelunky HD's first area's 3 great songs, though I appreciate it does fit the theme of the level.

The culmination of all these things makes the first area game a complete slog and will definitely put off would-be new players.

Post-Dwelling

Once you're past the first area the game is actually incredibly fun, Jungle and Volcana are both equally interesting areas. They both have lots of variation and extra flair added to them. Volcana having dead are restless, dark and the factory variations which are rare and exciting to come across + Vlad's castle and the Jungle having dead are restless, dark + the black market and any other variations I've not yet seen. Both areas contain unique, fun and challenging mobs without being overbearing (moles, lizards)

The Olmec fight is okay, it's kind of silly that on the second stage you practically just AFK whilst he destroys the level so you can decide if you want to go to temple or tide pool, but it's okay and i appreciate olmec is kind of a nice homage to the first game if anything even if the fight isn't great.

From my experience Tide Pool, Ice Caves and Babylon are all good zones although I think Babylon's mobs are a little bit boring mechanically even if their artwork is awesome, I've not played enough of temple to comment. Although all of the zones except for maybe temple are far more laid back than the clusterfuck that is dwelling and it causes the games' overall progression to feel disjointed and weird as the game is seemingly getting easier from the first area.

I will note that Tide Pool is a particularly beautiful zone with a brilliant soundtrack and comforting colours on the eyes, I think the balance there is absolutely spot on and it's plenty interesting with the different shops, Excalibur to retrieve, levers which you can interact with to alter the level + other things in the back layer I've not yet worked out.

The problem with all these great zones and pieces of content is that when you die (and you will die a lot) you are sent back to the insanely grating and unfun first zone which really kills motivation to play in general for me. I generally am more upset over having to play on dwelling again than I am about losing all my gear and progress. However I do appreciate the game has only been out for a few days and there is a certain amount of time that needs to pass before people properly adjust, especially HD veterans.

If you are considering buying this game and have not played Spelunky HD, I strongly suggest you go play that before you make a decision as it is on sale fairly frequently and is a great game, especially for its low cost.

I hope the Spelunky 2 team makes some adjustments to Dwelling, either mob spawning being toned down, moles and lizards are adjusted (health, speed or something else) or at least spawn crates more frequently throughout the level to give the player a chance in terms of resources.

-

Drill on Volcana almost always goes through lava which can make getting down to Vlad's castle practically impossible which means the time and resources spent getting the Udjat Eye are essentially wasted.

Completing Yang's quest in 1:2/1:3 is almost worthless as you aren't even guaranteed a single crate for the time it takes to do it

Having played the first one a lot, my review is gonna sound unfair at times but bear in mind despite all the cons I'm going about, I'm giving it a positive review since the game is obviously good and a great purchase choice, especially on sale.

Spelunky 2 builds up on all the hard time you had before, making it incredibly hard to go through the game. It's still fun and addictive as hell, bringing a lot to discover and fresh ideas. Also great artwork and animation. And fantastic gameplay. Seriously the game's really good, let me just vent out a little:

Where the problems start, at least for me: the game is somewhat obtuse every now and then. Some sections break the momentum and you're in the middle of something that's not that fun at all, like when the elevator goes through a lava pool, or those infuriating moles don't make up their minds, or having to search for the correct statue, and so on. The number of traps, plus the two ghosts mechanics, get in the way of wanting to search an area better. I get it's part of the difficulty, but it's still something that keeps someone from exploring the game, which I would debate is a good idea. And still the game finds other ways to punish you, like losing Qilin to the ceiling lasers and ruining your run.

Spelunky 2, for me, unfortunately ended up being more frustrating than fun. If you're just playing for the regular ending and not touching it again, then I'd say the game is on point in terms of difficulty and punishment. It's said every death in Spelunky 1 is by your own fault. I'm not so sure about that, but that's definitely not the case here. The game will be upfront unfair now, expect that, and try to laugh in the process.

It is just like the original.
Except now it's completely refreshed.
It may look like a lot of the same game mechanics are being used, but there are different physics, different worlds, different items. It's Spelunky except now you don't know anything about it again. Spelunky 2 is an opportunity to play Spelunky again and relearn all the unique characteristics of the enemies and traps.
Just like before, the walls are shifting again.

However, 200 hours into the game it becomes repetitive. The first area is boring and excruciating to play through. All of the deaths are insta kills and half of them aren't the players fault.
I'm uninstalling the game now because it is just incredibly unfair and monotonous which ruins replay value and overall game enjoyment. But the game still installed some wonderful memories in me. The music, graphics, and gameplay are all very nostalgic. It's the insta kills that ruin the game for me.

So I've loved the Spelunky series for over a decade at this point. I had thousands of runs on Spelunky classic, and about 50 or so hours on the HD remake. When the sequel came out, I was extremely excited! And then I wasn't, because it's hard as fuck. 

I considered it a miracle to get to the jungle area in Spelunky 2 when I first started playing it. Anything beyond that was absolutely unreal to consider. I played for about 5 hours before dropping it completely. 

But my problem was that I was expecting Spelunky HD (Part 2), rather than a proper sequel. The old tricks won't work, there's too much that has changed for me to expect to be good from the start. And this is a good thing! The sequel changes enough of the formula to stand apart from the other two games. But I didn't appreciate that at first, hence why I ragequit. 

After playing it for a bit more, I still haven't beaten it, but I've made it past Olmec, past the Ice Caves, into Neo-Babylon. I'm getting better all the time.

I actually thought that maybe my skills had deteriorated for a bit - but I downloaded Spelunky HD and beat it on my first try. It just goes to show you that Mossmouth has done a fantastic job of adding variety to the game and increased the difficulty so that people like me who've played Classic and HD will not just stroll through this in a few playthroughs. 

Buy it at full price - this is a game well worth it. Buy it for the difficulty and attention to detail!

The Full Spelunky is probably one of the hardest achievements in the history of video game achievements. It requires complete mastery of all aspects of one of the toughest games created. It's a major accomplishment, no doubt, but for something so difficult, it's pretty common. 1.4% of Steam players have The Full Spelunky. How? Simple. Once you start playing any Spelunky game, especially the best and most refined among them, you can't stop until you've reached the highest level of play possible. Spelunky 2 has an extremely strong pull. It's a black hole, and the event horizon is just after you reach the third set of areas. Make it there and you can no longer help yourself. At that level of skill, the most annoying parts of the game fade out, and the rest of your journey is a blast.

Ever play a game you like a lot, decide to spice it up by adding a mod that increases options and makes it more difficult - only to find it fun, but upsets the dev created balance, so you eventually go back?  That's what Spelunky 2 feels like - a fun variety mod of Spelunky with extra stuff and higher difficulty, but not as streamlined and well-balanced as the original.  

Spelunky is a great game.  I didn't think it was perfect, but it had a lot of stuff to do, tight controls, high challenge, and a really engaging quick loop.  Spelunky 2 mostly maintains this...  But increases the challenge, increases the number of instant death traps, makes the first area more irritating (the moles and lizards aren't fun obstacles, at all), adds a couple of bosses that are mostly tedious (does ANYONE like Quillback?) and slow down runs, all kinds of stuff like that.  

This is not to say Spelunky 2 isn't fun or a good game.  It absolutely is, and hence I still recommend it.  If you've played the hell out of Spelunky and want more, you should get it.  But if you're just picking one, I'd take the original.  It's a more fun experience, more replayable, and less frustrating.  

I should be clear here - I did beat Spelunky 2 without shortcuts (I didn't get to the secret levels, not sure if I care too, but I beat the core game).  It's doable.  Just a lot more annoying deaths, plus more parts that slow things down and make it less fun to go back to.

This game came out of nowhere for me, and yet a couple hundred hours later it's somehow managed to cement itself as one of my favorite games of all time.

Spelunky 2 is deceptively simple. The basic actions have hidden depth that you have to discover over time, and you'll realize very quickly that the game isn't going to pull any punches even at the start. Yet in spite of the games utterly ruthless and unforgiving nature, in the beginning the feeling of constantly making progress will reward you enough to keep you playing, learning new tricks and mechanics, and improving at the game without even realizing it at times. You'll look forward to each new discovery with equal parts anticipation and dread for how it's going to end up getting you killed. And yet as you play you'll realize that nearly every single one of your deaths were entirely avoidable, and you'll usually know precisely how you fucked up. Spelunky 2 makes it abundantly clear that the only barrier to success is your own knowledge and mastery. 

To compliment this idea, despite having randomly generated levels, Spelunky 2 is very consistent, reliable, and mostly avoids common trappings of games that rely heavily on random elements. In the end, while getting good luck on items is desirable, no matter how well your run is going you can still die to many of the same mistakes that you could die to at the very start. And yet looking at the other side of this coin, the game can always be somewhat reasonably completed front to back without ever picking up anything at all. And while the levels are random, you'll inevitably start to understand and anticipate the world gen for each area. Anything involved in chains/quests will always spawn in the levels you expect them to, and hell, you can even skip entire quest chains if you're good enough to pull it off.

I'm writing this recommendation having just finished acquiring every achievement in the game. The process of learning and mastering this game is one of the most satisfying experiences I've had in gaming. Even when hitting roadblocks, sometimes taking weeks to get by in the case of some achievements, the feeling of pushing past made it well worth it in the end for me. I'd even go as far as to say that this is a game I wouldn't mind forgetting everything about, just so I could experience the thing again.

At this point, the only concrete goal I have left in sight is making it through Cosmic Ocean to 7-99. I don't know if I'll ever get there, but damned if I'm not gonna keep coming back to this game to try. 


Oh, and if there's one bad thing I can say about it, it's that having one music track for each area does suck quite a bit after you've listened to the Dwelling theme 1500+ times. Compared to Spelunky HD having 4+ tracks for most areas, not to mention having generally better music overall, it can be a surprising drag on 2 at times. Doesn't take away from the rest of the game though.
