This game is everything a Spelunky sequel could ever hope to be. I have probably around 300 hours in Spelunky HD, but it still took me about 30 hours to beat this game, and another 60 to discover and complete the true ending, and I enjoyed almost every minute of it.

The only complaint I have is the abundance of instant kills that are present in the game, and how brutally punishing they can be. For someone like me going in blind and refusing to look on the internet for help, it can be frustrating to spend an entire day of attempts to reach a new area, only to die instantly because you didn't know what a new enemy did, then have to go through the whole process all over again for each new enemy. This complaint is largely solved by the inclusion of shortcut tunnels and seeded runs though, so I give Spelunky 2 a 10/10 score still.

A true masterpiece!

Perfectly designed risk and reward gameplay.

Spelunky 2 is a masterpiece.

The typically fair, but brutally challenging randomness of the generated maps, plus the endless interactions this game has, will provide you with endless goals to strive for. 

The difficulty is somewhat dynamic with multiple endings, and multiple zones to choose from along your way, each with their own unique enemies, traps, npcs, items, and even bosses! 

With it's ultra responsive controls, combined with smooth animations, navigating through the different environments feels perfect, and everything you do, purposeful.

As you learn how enemies move, traps work, and most importantly: how to utilize your whip and items you find, you'll eventually find yourself at the victory screen feeling more accomplished than ever. 

The only thing that might steer you away is it's extreme difficulty. Don't let it's charming nature and sprite-work fool you; nearly everything in this game is designed to end your life if you aren't careful. Despite how much fun the game is, if you take it too seriously it'll piss you off. You'll call the developer things you have never even heard of before. Sometimes though, your death is so spectacular that it feels like a win, especially if you can use shadow play or something to record the moment to share with your friends later.  

I highly recommend that if you are getting particularly frustrated to simply take a break. I often find that my best runs are the first one of the day, or after a long rest. The dwelling is also the most difficult zone in my opinion, so if you can get past 1-4, you can beat Tiamat. Also, don't be afraid to read guides and watch other players. There is no way any one player could figure out everything in this game. I even suspect as of the time of this review, that there may still be secrets left.

So grab your hamter or grab your friends and journey into the forever shifting rabbit hole.
Good Luck, and may Kali be pleased with you.

I've been thinking about how I can review this game and be able to talk about everything I like about it. I've realised that this is an impossible task, but I will do my best and talk about everything that stands out to me. Compared to the original Spelunky HD, this game just demolishes it in literally every category except one. and you know what? Spelunky HD is my second favourite game in the genre. The only thing Spelunky HD has over Spelunky 2 is the music, with there only being about 2 tracks per area (main theme and dark level theme) compared to Spelunky HD's about 4 tracks per area. Spelunky HD has the better OST, but that almost feels like a nitpick. Similarly to the last game, this is the most replayable game I have ever played in my life. This is due in part to the slow uncovering of separate objectives and the discovering of new areas. This brings me to arguably the best addition to this game. Branching paths. While Spelunky HD was replayable to no end, every run took you to the same 4 main areas (or 5 areas if you were cool); Spelunky HD is a short game, and that wasn't an accident. Spelunky 2, however, while not being much longer, is a lot denser. I know this was said by Derek Yu himself in the overview trailer but I mean he was right. There is simply a lot more to do here (which adds to that replayability). People have been saying that the game is "too difficult" or "not fair"; This is what I have to say to those people: this is a sequel to the game Spelunky. Of course it's going to be difficult and occasionally unfair. I have had my fair share of runs ended or impaired due to bad luck, and while I'm not going to argue that people should "get better" I am going to argue that people who bought this game knew or should have known exactly what kind of game they were adding to their steam library. Spelunky 2 is my favourite 2D platformer of all time, and this is coming from the person who's fondest memory is playing New Super Mario Brother Wii with his dad. Screw the Wii and screw Mario. Spelunky 2 is a masterpiece and will be looked back as such in years to come.

The secrets and satisfaction you gain from uncovering them in this game is more than enough to last you many years of replaying this game over and over. For gamers looking for the most outragously frustrating experience out there (I'm looking at your Dark Souls and Bloodborn fans) this is it. You won't find another game more challenging than this. The amount of times of shouted out in frustration because of the absolute bullshit ways you can die in this is inumerable. However when you complete any objective in the game at all you feel so satisfied. Whether it be to progress further than you have on a run or completing any side objectives. I highly recommend joining the Spelunky 2 discord, The people there are beyond nice and you can get good practice playing with them.

A warning though, this game has its fair share of bullshit. There are fair ways to die and there are many many ways you can die where it honestly feels like you couldn't have made it through an area without prior knowledge, which is impossible in a game like this unless you're doing a seeded run, which you can't do unless you've already played through the game entirely at least once.

Can be frustrating at times, but it rewards learning the mechanics of the game and there is just so much packed into this game beyond just the main boss itself. Tons of replay-ability because of this. Progressing really feels like an accomplishment. 

On the downside the first biome (the dwelling) can often be the most frustrating. Some rng can screw you, and it feels like the procedural generation could really improve in this first area especially.

Spelunky 2 managed to take absolutely everything I adored about the original, and expand upon it. Whereas the first game felt like an arcade game you'd pay a quarter to enter a quirky world full of diverse environments in rapid succession, Spelunky 2 feels more like a 2D adventure game, with beautiful, atmospheric environments that feel just as individual as the original. The game is fun solo or with friends, and will keep you coming back with that "one more run" mentality. Cannot recommend this enough to any roguelike or platformer fan.

This game is a great achievement of tough but fair design across the board, from the levels to enemies to bosses. Pretty much anything can (and will) kill you. The progression is solely gated around your skill, and you will get better as you play and learn more about the game.

My major issues stem from the multiplayer co-op. the online interface sucks, some issues include:
-winning a run in multiplayer boots you to the main menu
-cannot change an settings (audio/video) mid multiplayer run

The multiplayer has issues but is perfectly playable, and is a great time with friends. If you're looking for a challenging game with tight controls heavy replay value, a lot of unlockables/secrets, and dopamine coursing through the veins (if you can handle some frustration), I can recommend Spelunky 2 easily.

suffering

This game saved my life.

I am 60.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and adopted our son together. They are now both 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I found myself lost and miserable. I was self destructive. I got so mad one day from everything spiraling out of my control that I punched some concrete in a moment of overwhelming emotion. That caused me to break my 5th metacarpal in my right hand... my working hand... my games hand.. the hand that I held and carried my children to bed with.. The hand I desperately needed to make sure I could continue to provide.

After learning of the severity of my self-inflicted damage, I was borderline suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man with no history of depression or anxiety. I have never had fits of rage, or been one to break down and cry, but I was in a low spot that just really buried me from being able to see the light on the other side.

Having nothing better to do, I searched for a game I could play, ONE HANDED while I recovered. I somehow stumbled upon this game and read some of the reviews. I decided that it had to be worth a shot... I must admit, I didn't beat the game, or play nearly as long as some of you. In fact, I may have only played this game a day or two.. With that being said, after doing so, I had a new found joy and hope for life. I was able to put behind me the pain and suffering that had been cast over me. I was able to experience other peoples joy and happiness. I was able to see the fruits of my "labor". I relaxed for 5 ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ minutes to this music long enough to realize that I was going to be okay.

After coming to that realization, I turned the game off, and I went back to work. It hurt my hand like hell but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so damn sorry for myself, and I became the father I needed to be in that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving as.

Today, I am close friend with my kids mother. We don't fight, or argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents, and friends.

I now have 3 kids. My third child is, wait for it, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my own separation, and we just stumbled in to each others life unexpectedly. We have been in a relationship for a year now, and are very happy together.

Moral of the story, you never know what life holds in store for you, and if I would have given up when all the odds were stacked against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realise that.

There is this saying: "If you want to make god laugh tell him about your plans." And I think this is what this game is all about.
Somehow the game ends up encouraging you to overestimate your abilities and to bite off more than you can chew in the very limited time given to you to complete each level. As the result eventually you end up failing horribly. (It is actually possible to complete the game in multiple ways which you can choose depending on your arrogance as you progress through the game but you almost never succeed, because you are forced to act fast and in the hurry you almost always end up making SOME kind of a stupid mistake and failing.)
But that's not necessary a bad thing. That's what gives this game an infinite amount of replayability and the fun never runs out. It's difficult to learn and difficult to master. But even if you are a n00b the amount of fun you get makes up for that.
If you are interested in this game then I recommend to start with Spelunky 1 (the "HD" version from 2013). If you start with Spelunky 2 instead then you will miss some of the story and also it will be more difficult to start playing than it actually needs to be. So start with Spelunky 1 if you didn't play it yet and try to complete it's most difficult route (which means "going through hell") before you start with Spelunky 2. It's not horribly wrong to just start with Spelunky 2, but as someone who played and liked both of these games I don't recommend it.

The difficulty is certainly higher, but unlike Spelunky where you generally feel that any mistakes are your own fault, in Spelunky 2 there are a lot more enemies etc. that just feel a bit cheap. 
I found myself using the shortcut to the second area all the time after I unlocked it, as the first area just feels the same every time; if I do play it, an incredible number of runs will end right there, becoming rather frustrating.

Overall though I do recommend it, but I would recommend playing the first game beforehand if you haven't yet done so; or if you want an experience that is challenging but less frustrating.

This sequel has improved on just about everything that the original had to offer, with more worlds to explore, the addition of mini quests, ride-able mounts, and new gear. Whether you are a long time spelunker or are new to the indie platforming series, I highly recommend this game.

A lot of my review is targeted more towards those who have played one of the two original games, but for those who are new bear with me.

A few things in particular I enjoyed game play and control wise was the addition of the auto run option, as the toll your fingers took from pressing down a button for the entire time you are playing can now be avoided entirely. In this iteration of Spelunky, being able to attack enemies that have been stunned with other objects is very much appreciated, as it use to be that you would have to wait for an enemy to become conscious again before you could land another hit on them.

Some things to keep in mind while playing this game is that this game follows the formula of if you die, you go back to the start, which may be frustrating to some people. There are a lot more ways to die in this game, and quite a few of them are one-hit kills, some of which you can see in the game trailers. While these may appear to be unfair in nature, the longer you play the game, the more tactical you may become and will wisen up on ways to avoid or destroy said obstacles. 

This game has a lot of replay value, and for those who are considering getting this game, I would recommend trying to get all of the steam achievements legitimately. There are three different endings (not saying what they are for those who want the blind experience) and there are may play styles you can follow, being a classic law abiding citizen, a master criminal (which was ultimately what nearly every run ended up looking like in Spelunky HD), a saver of animals, or a fool (shh its a secret!) among other roles.

Once you have gotten "The Full Spelunky" I would recommend trying out mods for the single player experience, as my playtime has doubled just playing the Spelunky 2 randomizer and reverse game mods (you can look for instructions to safely install mods online if you are really interested). You can also use mods to practice techniques that otherwise may be costly in a normal run.

I don't want to say too much, as part of the fun of the Spelunky series is finding out all of the secrets for yourself and experiencing the rush of finding a secret location or item. For now I will leave you with my recommendations for this game, and happy spelunking!

This is a very amazing game that never gets old. There is always something different that you can try. A lot of new players might feel discouraged at first due the large amount of deaths that will occur, but these are important as they teach the player about many different mechanics. For example: A player may encounter an arrow trap and they get shot the first time, but then they learn that they can trigger them with other objects. A lot of these deaths are very ridiculous and make me laugh. A large part of this game is dying, and even after playing for over 200 hours, I rarely get runs that go well.

The Game Nobody Asked For

This is an excellent sequel to the original. It maintains the feel and core gameplay elements from the first, but changes the levels, enemies, and hidden content enough to make it feel distinctly new and unique. It still has the addictive loop that so many roguelike games have, as soon as you lose a run you are itching to start another. It also has the ridiculous Rube Goldberg style deaths which are infuriating but also entertaining, in a masochistic way. The co-op mode is especially fun, and is greatly improved over the original game. Be prepared to die a lot, but learn a little something with each death and steadily improve with playtime.

With Spelunky 2 Derek Yu went in over his head and forgot that the exploration part was the best part of Spelunky, not the insanely high difficulty. Back, when I still played Spelunky 1, I still went to school and had the time to put up with this difficulty but now, that I am working full time I tend to get too frustrated by it. 

With run after run failing, I also fail to laugh at my own failures, only leaving frustration. It certainly does not help that Spelunky 2 is even harder than its successor. I wonder which playerbase is catered here.

What was a huge plus for me, to be able to fail together with a friend online but sadly this is not possible either for now. In my opinion the online coop can maybe eliviate the frustration a littlebit because you "struggle together". But all of my friends are reluctant for coop due to Spelunky 2's high difficulty.

The image of Indie games having to be really hard is outdated because other Indie games of 2020 like Hades have proven that a well balanced difficulty curve works fine for all kinds of playerbases.

I pride myself on being very careful, focused, and precise. It is not possible in this game for me. I love it to death for that. Over and over again I get my ass handed to me by the same things. And it just gets better with friends. The ways in which you will accidentally and intentionally kill each other will be magnificent.

I don't know if I just suck at Spelunky now or if this game is just unreasonably hard. I have thousands of hours on the first Spelunky (on Xbox 360 - long gone now) and while that was a challenge to get into, I eventually got to the point where I could get to Yama every morning with my coffee. For context, I also have thousands of hours in Binding of Isaac. I'm used to some torturous gameplay.

This one, however.. I love the charm, and the look. A lot of the new mechanics are really intriguing! But I'm struggling to enjoy my experience because I can't get beyond the jungle or purple industrial area without getting my ass handed to me handily. 

I love Spelunky.. and maybe I do just suck now. But this lovable game is just a bit too punishing, even for seasoned Spelunkers. I would recommend it - but it's going to take a long time (or some difficulty reduction on Mossmouth's end) before I can truly enjoy this one. Maybe my recommendation will change down the road. For now, it's just too hard to enjoy.

Spelunky 2 is objectively a good game. The movement is responsive, the combat is challenging, the soundtrack is expansive, and the rogue-like genre is inherently replayable. 

However, I will say that Spelunky 2 is difficult. Not mechanically difficult per say, but the game never holds your hand. If you want to play this, you will die hundreds of times, and then some. Don't expect to walk in and know what you're doing. But for those who are willing to take their lumps and learn from their mistakes, Spelunky 2 is exceptionally rewarding. 

Don't be afraid to look to the community for help when learning, there's always more to learn about Spelunky 2 and I certainly wouldn't be half as good without the community. 

All in all, Spelunky 2 is an exceptional sequel to the original game, with great QOL improvements and more to explore and mess with. If this sounds appealing to you, try it out. If you're not sure, why not give it a try anyway?
Awesome!

This. This is just a joke right?... Okay, calm down calm down, (Breathes) Yes Spelunky HD has a sequel. Indeed. 
What do you normally expect from a sequel? To be worse... Right?

IT'S NOT THE CASE HERE. This game is just.. Incredible. Like absolutely an improvement to every aspect of Spelunky HD. It's harder, It's Bigger, It's More fun, It's a little more revolutionary... Spelunky 2 is Spelunky-ier.

For starters let's talk about traps. Ah yes my favourite part of Spelunky HD and also the bane of most players. Let me explain.

There is a lot more traps (Some come back like the Arrow trap, Crush trap, Spikes, Lava, Water, Boulder) with some being old ones remade. For example, remember the tiki trap? Remember when in your first hours of HD they would get you sooo often, those traps so damn tricky right? You thought That after completing the game 100% and all other shit you would be safe, right? Let me introduce you to Totem traps in the FIRST AREA. Yes they do deal 2 damage instead of 4 but they behave exactly the same. Enemies are also remade. The bat was so annoying in HD right? Yeah how funny it would be when you find Rolling lizards with 3 hitpoints that can charge and slowly kill you with their powerful rolls. Or Meeting the moles, which dig through the ground (Not Wood) and can pop up from the ceiling and really traverse the whole level! Who's got teeth like spades and need no shades? CAVE MOLE! CAVE MOLE! This is balanced because of health being easier to come by, Other than  saving Monty, Percy or Poochi, you can cook turkeys (Find that out for yourself :D). You'll also have to pick between branching paths as you go deeper into the challenges that await you.. And in some cases, One can be better than the other! One of them is a Volcano inspired area with a lot of instadeath lava, And one can even be an place from HD! Please play this game for the love of god. I just want to say.. This is a love letter, for the Spelunky community. Thank you Mossmouth, for working on this game so hard. The only bad thing i can get in my mind is no variety in the official soundtrack of the game. But this is replaced by Dynamic music and It's just more atmospheric. Actually this game can predict how you feel by the music so prepare for that. This is my longest ever review (Even longer than the Spelunky HD one) But. Just straight up buy this game, But prepare yourself for one of the hardest games ever created. Myst3ry's out. The more i die, the more i groan, the more i wanna get to tiamat's throne








Edit: I am definetely getting better at this game, Just speedrunned it, and almost reached the secret area. EDIT 2: I HAVE DONE IT
I HAVE COMPLETED THE SECRET ROUTE.
